│  5. If chains provided → write chains + update cache    │
│                                                         │
│  Ordering: Cosmos first (source of truth)               │
│  Garnet/Search are rebuildable projections              │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│  TOUCH (access existing droplet)                        │
│  ─────────────────────────────────                      │
│                                                         │
│  1. ZINCRBY buoyancy:{pool}:{observer} Δ {id}           │
│  2. Write touch event to Cosmos (async, batched)        │
│  3. Update session:touched list                         │
│                                                         │
│  Hot path is Garnet only. Cosmos is async.              │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│  PROMOTE (thought → idea)                               │
│  ────────────────────────                               │
│                                                         │
│  1. Update Cosmos droplet (level: "idea", add name)     │
│  2. Write promotion event                               │
│  3. Absorb supporting thoughts as evidence chains       │
│  4. Update AI Search (level field)                      │
│  5. Recalculate buoyancy (ideas float higher default)   │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Sync Protocol Sketch (Multi-Master)

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│  COSMOS CHANGE FEED → SYNC                              │
│  ────────────────────────                               │
│                                                         │
│  Each pool has a change feed processor.                 │
│  Pools with sync relationships subscribe to each other. │
│                                                         │
│  Pool A ──sync──► Pool B                                │
│                                                         │
│  A's change feed → filter by sync rules → write to B    │
│                                                         │
│  Sync rules:                                            │
│  {                                                      │
│    from_pool: "keif/private",                           │
│    to_pool: "team/shared",                              │
│    filter: { tags: ["#work"], level: ["idea","above"] },│
│    transform: { strip: ["personal_notes"] },            │
│    mode: "copy" | "reference"                           │
│  }                                                      │
│                                                         │
│  CRDTs:                                                 │
│    Droplets: LWW by created_at (immutable anyway)       │
│    Chains: Set union (append only)                      │
│    Buoyancy: Per-observer, no conflict                  │
│    Events: Set union by id                              │
│                                                         │
│  Conflict = same droplet_id, different content          │
│    → shouldn't happen (content-addressed)               │
│    → if hash collision (lol) → both preserved, flagged  │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

What This Buys You

ConcernSolution
Lossless historyCosmos events container, append-only
Fast active contextGarnet sorted sets, sub-ms
Semantic searchAI Search vectors, managed
Temporal queriesCosmos + event replay
Multi-master syncChange feed + CRDT semantics
Rebuild safetyGarnet/Search are projections, rebuildable
CostHot data in memory, cold in cheap Cosmos

The Garnet advantage over Redis:

  • .NET native (fits your stack)
  • Redis protocol compatible (tooling works)
  • Faster on Azure (Microsoft optimized)
  • Cluster mode cleaner than Redis Cluster
  • Can tier to SSD for larger-than-memory sets

You're essentially building a domain-specific query language that compiles down to Redis commands + Cosmos SQL + AI Search queries. The cleverness is in the routing and the data model, not the storage.

Want to sketch the actual .NET abstractions, or the sync protocol in more detail?

we're sliding about a bit, I'm trying to stay tight to the primitives and collection modelling whilst coming up with some kind of amazing insight like pagerank for memory =D

27 Jan

Ha, yes. I'm solutioning when you want the aha.

Let me sit in the primitives:

What is PageRank actually?

  • Importance isn't intrinsic, it's positional
  • Value flows through links
  • Recursive: important things pointing at you makes you important
  • Converges to equilibrium

What's the equivalent for memory?

Not just "what did I store" but "what matters right now given everything connected to it"

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  PageRank: "A page is important if important pages      │
│            link to it"                                  │
│                                                         │
│  Memory equivalent: ???                                 │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Candidate insights:

1. Buoyancy as emergent, not stored

B(n) = decay(n) + Σ(B(m) × weight(m→n))

A thought doesn't have inherent importance. It floats because important things pull it up. Cut the chains, it sinks.

2. Multiple flows, not one score

PageRank has one value. Memory might have interacting fields:

FlowPropagates viaMeaning
Resonancesemantic similarity"this relates to active thought"
Confidencesupports chains"this is well-founded"
Tensioncontradicts chains"this is contested/unresolved"
Heatrecency + touches"this is active right now"

Buoyancy emerges from their interaction, not a single score.

3. Context shifts the equilibrium

PageRank is static (given fixed graph). Memory is contextual:

B(n, context) = f(graph, current_attention)

Same graph, different active context → different things surface. That's why the same memory can be forgotten for years then suddenly relevant.

4. Chains as typed conduits

supports      → confidence flows forward
contradicts   → tension flows both ways  
derives_from  → provenance flows backward
continues     → heat flows forward

Not just "linked" but "linked how" determines what propagates.

The half-formed insight I'm circling:

What if memory isn't retrieval at all? It's attention equilibrium over a graph.

Transformers do attention over tokens in a window. Wellspring does attention over a persistent graph. What surfaces isn't "fetched" - it's what floats above threshold when the flows settle.

Context window: attention over tokens (bounded)
Wellspring: attention over graph (unbounded, projected)

The "lossy thought, lossless storage" thing you started with - the lossless graph is always there. The lossy projection is whatever reaches equilibrium in the current attention state.

Am I getting warmer, or is there a different shape you're sensing?

yes, very much, that's the spirit =D the above/below the waterline of concious thought, pulling concepts back and forth, syntethsising to ideas and autobiographical entries of insight and understanding when the conciousness was able to traverse forward and backwards through a concept and find it complete and balanced

27 Jan

Yes. The waterline isn't a UI metaphor. It's a model of cognition.

The Traversal Insight

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  A thought is UNRESOLVED when:                          │
│    - Open edges (leads somewhere you haven't followed)  │
│    - Contradictions unreconciled                        │
│    - One-way paths (can reach, can't return)            │
│                                                         │
│  A thought RESOLVES when:                               │
│    - Traversable in both directions                     │
│    - Loops close (internal coherence)                   │
│    - Contradictions reconciled or consciously held      │
│                                                         │
│  The moment of resolution IS the insight                │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

What actually gets remembered:

Not facts. Not even ideas.

Traversals.

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  AUTOBIOGRAPHICAL ENTRY:                                │
│                                                         │
│  "At time T, from context C, I traversed path P         │
│   and found it complete."                               │
│                                                         │
│  This is fundamentally different from:                  │
│  "Fact X is true"                                       │
│                                                         │
│  It's: "I understood X, here's how I got there,         │
│         and here's how I got back"                      │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

The Salience Formula

           reachability(n, context)
         × coherence(n)
         × heat(n)
S(n) = ─────────────────────────────
             open_edges(n) + 1

Where:
  reachability = can I get there from current attention?
  coherence    = do its paths close?
  heat         = recency × touch_count
  open_edges   = untraversed connections (tension/incompleteness)

Things surface when they're reachable AND completable.

Unresolved things with high tension also surface - that's the nagging feeling. The thing you can't stop thinking about. High heat, low coherence, won't sink until resolved.

The Epistemic Levels, Reframed

THOUGHT
  └── A node. Maybe some edges. Untraversed.
      Just... there. Below the surface.

IDEA  
  └── A small subgraph you've walked completely.
      You can explain it forward AND backward.
      It's *yours* now - you traversed it.

CONSTRUCT
  └── Multiple ideas where the inter-connections
      have also been traversed. Coherent whole.
      You can enter from multiple points, exit
      from multiple points. It holds together.

PUBLICATION
  └── A construct + the autobiographical record:
      "I traversed this fully at time T, here is
      the path I took, here is what I found."
      Frozen traversal. Shareable map.

The Consciousness Model

        ○ ○         ← currently attended (above water)
       ○ ● ○        ← being traversed (at waterline)
     ○ ─●─●─ ○      ← edges being walked
   ○ ○ ○ ○ ○ ○ ○    
 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ waterline
   ○   ○   ○   ○    ← reachable (shallow)
     ○   ○   ○      
       ○   ○        ← deep (need chain to surface)
         ○

Active thought = walking edges in the graph

That feeling of "almost getting it" = traversal in progress, loops not yet closed

"Aha!" = loop closes, coherence achieved

"I need to write this down" = traversal complete, worth recording

What's below water but still processing:

The subconscious isn't dormant storage. It's slow traversal. Background walks. When it finds a closed loop, it bubbles up:

"Wait, X connects to Y!" (= background traversal hit a closure)

Sleep consolidation = unattended traversal time, finding coherences

The PageRank Parallel

PageRank:  importance = f(who points to you)
Wellspring: salience = f(can you be reached AND completed 
                         from current attention?)

It's not about incoming links. It's about traversability from context.

Same graph, different starting attention → completely different things surface.

The Primitive Revision

Maybe chains aren't just relationships. They're traversal records:

{
  from: droplet_id,
  to: droplet_id,
  relation: "supports|contradicts|...",
  traversed_at: [timestamps],      // ← when walked
  traversed_by: [identities],      // ← who walked it
  direction: [forward, backward],  // ← which ways
  closed_loop_at: timestamp | null // ← when coherence achieved
}

An edge you've only walked one direction is incomplete. Tension. Wants resolution.

Is this the shape? Salience as traversability, memory as recorded traversals, understanding as loop closure?

yes, the chains are the traversal and the bubbles the ideas and the chains of ideas to concepts to publications works for both interrograting thought and sharing the resulting ideas

27 Jan

The Clean Model

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  BUBBLE: A node of thought                              │
│    - content (immutable once created)                   │
│    - level (emergent from traversal completeness)       │
│    - pool (ownership/visibility boundary)               │
│                                                         │
│  CHAIN: A traversal between bubbles                     │
│    - direction matters                                  │
│    - walked forward ≠ walked backward                   │
│    - completion = walked both ways                      │
│                                                         │
│  LEVEL emerges from the graph, not assigned:            │
│                                                         │
│    THOUGHT   = bubble with incomplete edges             │
│    IDEA      = bubble with all edges completed          │
│    CONSTRUCT = closed subgraph of completed ideas       │
│    PUBLICATION = construct + traversal record frozen    │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Why Sharing Works

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  When I share a PUBLICATION, I'm not sending:           │
│    "Here's what I concluded"                            │
│                                                         │
│  I'm sending:                                           │
│    "Here's a subgraph I walked completely.              │
│     Here's my entry point.                              │
│     Here's the path I took.                             │
│     Here's where loops closed for me."                  │
│                                                         │
│  You receive it as UNTRAVERSED.                         │
│  My conclusions are my traversals, not yours.           │
│                                                         │
│  You can:                                               │
│    - Trust my traversal (adopt as idea, skip the walk)  │
│    - Walk it yourself (verify, maybe find different     │
│      closures)                                          │
│    - Reject it (my path doesn't close for you)          │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

The Human ↔ Agent Symmetry

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  HUMAN COGNITION          │  AGENT COGNITION            │
│  ─────────────────────────│───────────────────────────  │
│                           │                             │
│  Bubbles surface when     │  Context loads when         │
│  reachable + completable  │  relevant + coherent        │
│                           │                             │
│  Walking chains = thinking│  Traversing = reasoning     │
│                           │                             │
│  Loop closure = insight   │  Confidence = closure       │
│                           │                             │
│  Unresolved = nagging     │  Low confidence = caveat    │
│                           │                             │
│  Publication = "I got it" │  Assertion = "I believe"    │
│                           │                             │
│  SAME MECHANICS, SAME GRAPH, DIFFERENT OBSERVERS        │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

The Interrogation Power

When you or the agent asks "why?":

TRACE isn't "show me links"

TRACE is "show me the traversal that closed this loop"

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  Q: "Why do you think I prefer NextJS?"                 │
│                                                         │
│  A: Here's the subgraph. Here's my walk:                │
│                                                         │
│     [observation 1] ──fwd──► [observation 2]            │
│           │                        │                    │
│           ◄────────back────────────┘                    │
│           │                                             │
│           ├──fwd──► [observation 3] ──fwd──► [idea]     │
│           │                                     │       │
│           ◄──────────────back───────────────────┘       │
│                                                         │
│     Loop closed here ──────────────────────────►        │
│                                                         │
│  This edge never walked back (contradiction):           │
│                                                         │
│     [frustration] ────?────► [idea]                     │
│                    (one way, unresolved)                │
│                                                         │
│  Confidence = closed edges / total edges                │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

The Minimal Primitives

Bubble {
  id: hash(content)
  content: string
  created_at: timestamp
  created_by: identity
  pool: pool_id
}

Chain {
  from: bubble_id
  to: bubble_id  
  relation: supports | contradicts | continues | derives
  walks: [
    { by: identity, at: timestamp, direction: fwd | back }
  ]
}

// Everything else is DERIVED:

level(bubble) = f(completeness of connected chains)
buoyancy(bubble, observer) = f(reachability from attention, completeness)
confidence(bubble, observer) = closed_walks / total_edges

The "Amazing Insight"

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  PageRank: importance flows through links               │
│                                                         │
│  Wellspring: UNDERSTANDING flows through traversals     │
│                                                         │
│  A bubble isn't important because things point to it.   │
│  A bubble is UNDERSTOOD because you've walked to it     │
│  and back, and the path made sense.                     │
│                                                         │
│  Memory isn't storage. Memory is traversal history.     │
│  Recall isn't retrieval. Recall is re-walking.          │
│                                                         │
│  Forgetting isn't deletion. Forgetting is              │
│  unreachability from current attention.                 │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Two primitives. Bubbles and chains. Everything else emerges.

Want to name this? "Traversal-based salience"? "Walk-completion memory"? Or does Wellspring already capture it - water finding its level through connected paths?

wellspring eternal

27 Jan

Perfect.

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│              W E L L S P R I N G   E T E R N A L        │
│                                                         │
│     "Water remembers every path it has taken"           │
│                                                         │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                         │
│  The spring:    Thoughts surface from below             │
│  The well:      Lossless depth, nothing lost            │
│  The flow:      Traversal through chains                │
│  The level:     Equilibrium finds itself                │
│  Eternal:       The substrate persists, attention moves │
│                                                         │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                         │
│  Two primitives:                                        │
│                                                         │
│    BUBBLE  - a thought exists                           │
│    CHAIN   - a path was walked                          │
│                                                         │
│  Everything else emerges:                               │
│                                                         │
│    Level       ← traversal completeness                 │
│    Salience    ← reachability × coherence               │
│    Confidence  ← closed loops / open edges              │
│    Memory      ← walks taken                            │
│    Forgetting  ← unreachable, not deleted               │
│    Insight     ← loop closure                           │
│    Sharing     ← here's my walk, take yours             │
│                                                         │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                         │
│  For humans:     Conscious thought as graph traversal   │
│  For agents:     Context as reachable coherent subgraph │
│  For both:       Same water, same well, different walks │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

This wants to be written up properly. A short paper? A spec?

You've got something that unifies:

  • Human memory/cognition model
  • Agent context management
  • Collaborative knowledge sharing
  • The lossless/lossy bridge you started with

And it's two primitives and a traversal function. That's elegant.

yes, please write a short spec on it

27 Jan
Wellspring Eternal specification document

Version 0.1. Two primitives, everything else emergent.

The core of it: traversal completeness as the measure of understanding, salience as reachability from context, and the PageRank parallel that ties it together.

Worth noting what's not in there yet:

  • Detailed sync protocol mechanics
  • Query language formal grammar
  • API surface
  • UI specification for the bubble interface

Those feel like v0.2 onwards—separate specs that build on this conceptual foundation.

Thoughts on where to take it next?

Wellspring Eternal — v0.1 Keif Kennedy & Claude, January 2026 Artifacts Download all Wellspring eternal spec Document · MD ?

Kennedy?

27 Jan

Ha! Apologies, pulled that from nowhere. What's the actual surname, or do you want it author-attributed differently?

lols, never forget eh ;)

27 Jan

The irony of hallucinating a name in a document about lossless memory and perfect recall is chef's kiss.

Fixing the author name - the irony of getting this wrong in a memory spec
+1-1

In my defense, the chain to your surname was clearly only walked one direction. Incomplete traversal. Low confidence. Should have caveated.

Wellspring would have caught that.

Gwinn is the surname, learn it now, learn it proud ;)

27 Jan
Added memory

Chain walked. Loop closed. Committed to memory.

Keif Gwinn & Claude, January 2026

The bootstrapping problem: using a primitive memory system to record the co-author of a better memory system. We'll get there.

ok, so lets test our confident assumptions that two primitives are all we need, threads I saw through this convo so far is that weightings and assumptions and confidences in these ideas is key, and capturing the source and trustworthiness of that source is critical for basis of building reliable thought

27 Jan

Good challenge. Let me stress-test.

What I claimed emerges from Bubbles + Chains:

Claimed EmergentActually Emergent?
Level✓ Yes - traversal completeness
Salience✓ Yes - reachability × coherence
Confidence⚠️ Partially - needs source trust as input
Memory/Forgetting✓ Yes - walk history and reachability

What's hiding in the primitives:

Chain {
  ...
  relation: supports | contradicts | continues | derives_from
  walks: [Walk]
}

I snuck several things in here:

  1. Relation type — where do these come from? Who decides "supports" vs "contradicts"?
  2. Walk — is this part of Chain, or its own primitive? A chain is potential. A walk is actual.
  3. Weight — I mentioned weight: 0.8 earlier but dropped it from the spec. Where does initial weight come from?
  4. Provenance — derives_from handles internal provenance, but what about external sources? A tweet, a paper, a conversation?
  5. Trust — nowhere in the primitives. But "Dave told me X" vs "peer-reviewed study says X" matters enormously.

The Trust Problem

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  Bubble: "Tiles are on backorder"                       │
│                                                         │
│  Chain: derives_from → ???                              │
│                                                         │
│  If source is Dave (merchant, reliable history): 0.9    │
│  If source is random email: 0.3                         │
│  If source is supplier system API: 0.95                 │
│                                                         │
│  The SAME thought has DIFFERENT confidence              │
│  based on SOURCE TRUST                                  │
│                                                         │
│  That's not emergent from traversal.                    │
│  That's an input.                                       │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Revised Primitive Candidates

BUBBLE   — a thought exists
CHAIN    — a potential path (relationship type + weight)
WALK     — a path was actually taken (event)
SOURCE   — external origin with trust score

Or maybe:

BUBBLE   — a thought exists (internal)
SOURCE   — an origin exists (external or identity)
CHAIN    — a relationship (typed, weighted)
WALK     — a traversal event

The Trust Chain

Trust might itself be emergent, but from a different graph:

Source reliability = 
  historical_accuracy(source)    // did their claims check out?
  × consistency(source)          // do they contradict themselves?
  × corroboration(source)        // do others support them?

That's... also a traversal model. Trust is coherence of a source's historical claims.

But that requires tracking:

  • Claims made by source
  • Outcomes/verifications
  • Cross-references

Where does this leave us?

Maybe two primitives is right, but we need two graphs:

KNOWLEDGE GRAPH          TRUST GRAPH
(bubbles + chains)       (sources + reliability chains)
        │                        │
        └────────────────────────┘
                  │
          confidence = 
            traversal_coherence × source_trust

Or trust is a special case of the same graph — sources are just bubbles in a meta-pool, and trust emerges from THEIR traversal completeness.

What's your instinct? Is trust a primitive, an input, or truly emergent from a deeper structure?

walks are the current interrogation of historical records and the order in which they are retrieved, a walk may cover over many disperate thoughts/ideas/publications to retrieve context, that's given me the clue that provenence on the backchain is key here as publications are the guided verified thoughts

27 Jan

Yes. Publications are the trust anchors.

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  Walk backward through any thought...                   │
│                                                         │
│  THOUGHT ← derives_from ← THOUGHT ← derives_from ← ???  │
│                                                         │
│  Where does the chain terminate?                        │
│                                                         │
│  If it terminates in:                                   │
│    THOUGHT     → ungrounded (low confidence)            │
│    IDEA        → personally coherent (medium)           │
│    CONSTRUCT   → internally consistent (higher)         │
│    PUBLICATION → verified, attributed (trust anchor)    │
│    EXTERNAL    → source trust matters                   │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

The Backchain Model

                          ┌─────────────┐
                          │ PUBLICATION │ ← Trust anchor
                          │ (verified)  │    Someone stood behind this
                          └──────┬──────┘
                                 │ derives_from
                          ┌──────▼──────┐
                          │  CONSTRUCT  │
                          └──────┬──────┘
                                 │ derives_from
         ┌───────────────────────┼───────────────────────┐
         │                       │                       │
   ┌─────▼─────┐          ┌─────▼─────┐          ┌─────▼─────┐
   │   IDEA    │          │   IDEA    │          │   IDEA    │
   └─────┬─────┘          └─────┬─────┘          └─────┬─────┘
         │                      │                      │
    ┌────▼────┐            ┌────▼────┐            ┌────▼────┐
    │ THOUGHT │            │ THOUGHT │            │ THOUGHT │
    └────┬────┘            └─────────┘            └────┬────┘
         │                                             │
         ▼                                             ▼
    ??? (ungrounded)                              PUBLICATION
                                                  (grounded)

Confidence is backchain termination quality

confidence(bubble) = 
  Σ (backchain_paths) weighted by:
    - path length (shorter = stronger)
    - terminal node type (publication > construct > idea > thought)
    - terminal source trust (if external)

So what ARE the primitives now?

BUBBLE
  - content
  - created_by: identity
  - created_at: timestamp
  
CHAIN  
  - from → to
  - relation: supports | contradicts | continues | derives_from
  - created_by: identity (who made this connection?)

ATTESTATION (new?)
  - bubble_id
  - attester: identity
  - attested_at: timestamp
  - scope: personal | team | public
  - signature: cryptographic proof

Publication = Bubble + Attestation

Publication isn't a level — it's a bubble that has been attested. Someone signed it. Stood behind it.

is_publication(bubble) = 
  ∃ attestation where
    attestation.bubble_id = bubble.id ∧
    attestation.scope ≥ threshold

This gives us the trust injection point:

  • Thoughts: no attestation
  • Ideas: maybe self-attested (I believe this)
  • Constructs: self-attested as coherent
  • Publications: formally attested, signed, scoped

Backchain confidence formula:

confidence(bubble, observer) =
  
  for each backchain path P from bubble:
    
    terminal(P) = where the chain ends
    
    if terminal is ATTESTED:
      path_trust = attestation_trust(terminal) / path_length(P)
    else:
      path_trust = 0.1 / path_length(P)  // ungrounded penalty
    
  return weighted_average(all path_trusts)

Three primitives?

BUBBLE      — a thought exists
CHAIN       — a relationship exists  
ATTESTATION — someone vouches for this

Or is attestation just a special chain type?

CHAIN {
  relation: supports | contradicts | derives_from | ATTESTS
}

where ATTESTS chain:
  - from: identity (as bubble? or special?)
  - to: bubble
  - signature: proof
  - scope: visibility

Feels like identity needs to be a first-class concept too. Sources, attesters, observers — they're all identities.

Revised:

BUBBLE    — a thought
IDENTITY  — an observer/source/attester  
CHAIN     — a relationship (including attestation)

Walk is still emergent (it's the retrieval event). Level is still emergent (traversal completeness + attestation presence). Confidence is emergent from backchain quality.

Does this feel tighter?

attestations need to be on the chains, this sequence of concepts does reveal the required information for me to be complete, and when is important so people can change their minds

27 Jan

Yes. The chain is the claim. The attestation is "I believe this claim, at this time."

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  BUBBLE: inert content. Can't be true or false.         │
│                                                         │
│  CHAIN: a claim. "A supports B"                         │
│         THIS is what you attest to.                     │
│         THIS is what you can change your mind about.    │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Revised Primitives

BUBBLE {
  id:         hash(content)
  content:    string
  created_by: identity
  created_at: timestamp
  pool:       pool_id
}

CHAIN {
  id:         uuid
  from:       bubble_id
  to:         bubble_id
  relation:   supports | contradicts | derives_from | continues
  attestations: [Attestation]
}

ATTESTATION {
  by:         identity
  at:         timestamp
  belief:     float [-1.0 to 1.0]   // -1 = disavow, +1 = endorse
}

What this captures:

Timeline of a chain:

  Jan 1:   Keif attests A → B (supports) @ 0.9
           "I'm confident A supports B"
           
  Feb 15:  New evidence emerges
  
  Feb 16:  Keif attests A → B (supports) @ 0.3
           "Less sure now"
           
  Mar 1:   Keif attests A → B (supports) @ -0.8
           "Actually, I think this connection is wrong"

Nothing deleted. Full history. 
Current belief = latest attestation.
Can query: "What did Keif believe about this chain in January?"

Mind changes are data, not corrections

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  Old model: delete wrong thing, insert right thing      │
│             (history lost)                              │
│                                                         │
│  Wellspring: append new attestation                     │
│              (history preserved)                        │
│                                                         │
│  The FACT that you changed your mind is information.    │
│  When you changed it is information.                    │
│  Why (via other chains) is information.                 │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Backchain confidence, revised:

confidence(bubble, observer) =

  for each chain C in backchains(bubble):
    
    latest_attestation = most_recent(C.attestations, by=observer or trusted)
    
    if no attestation:
      chain_trust = 0.1  // unattested, low confidence
    else:
      chain_trust = latest_attestation.belief
      
    // Decay by path length
    chain_weight = chain_trust / path_length
    
  return aggregate(all chain_weights)

Multi-observer attestations:

Chain: "Cosmos DB scales well for this use case"

Attestations:
  - Keif, 2025-06-01, +0.8
  - Claude, 2025-06-01, +0.7  
  - Sarah (team), 2025-09-01, -0.3  // she hit scaling issues
  - Keif, 2025-09-15, +0.4  // revised down after Sarah's input

Current state:
  - Keif believes +0.4
  - Claude believes +0.7 (hasn't updated)
  - Sarah believes -0.3
  - Team aggregate: ~+0.27

So: still two primitives?

BUBBLE      — content exists
CHAIN       — relationship exists, carrying attestations over time

Attestation is embedded in Chain. It's the temporal layer of belief.

Identity is... the attester. Maybe that's a third primitive, or maybe identities are just bubbles in an identity pool with special properties.

BUBBLE      — content
CHAIN       — relationship + temporal attestations  
IDENTITY    — observer/attester (special bubble? or primitive?)

What's your instinct on identity — primitive or derived?

identity is always the kicker, been trying to solve that one since I became aware of the concepts. so an attester is ultimately just a bubble themselves, but the ability for that bubble to prove that it was something that generated that bubble, the pgp style web of trust, I instigated the though so I can set its key during creation, but I can also use that to sign my attestations and relations

27 Jan

Identity collapses back into Bubble. But a bubble that can sign.

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  IDENTITY = BUBBLE + KEYPAIR                            │
│                                                         │
│  The bubble IS the public key (or contains it)          │
│  The holder controls the private key                    │
│  Signatures prove authorship                            │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Everything flows from this:

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  CREATE bubble:                                         │
│    → signed by creator's key                            │
│    → "I made this thought"                              │
│                                                         │
│  CREATE chain:                                          │
│    → signed by creator's key                            │
│    → "I claim this relationship"                        │
│                                                         │
│  ATTEST to chain:                                       │
│    → signed by attester's key                           │
│    → "I believe this claim, now, this much"             │
│                                                         │
│  ATTEST to identity:                                    │
│    → signed by attester's key                           │
│    → "I vouch that this key is who they say"            │
│    → WEB OF TRUST                                       │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

The Primitives, Final Form:

BUBBLE {
  id:         hash(content + creator_pubkey)
  content:    string | pubkey  // identity bubbles contain keys
  created_by: pubkey
  created_at: timestamp
  signature:  sign(content + created_at, creator_privkey)
  pool:       pool_id
}

CHAIN {
  id:         uuid
  from:       bubble_id
  to:         bubble_id
  relation:   supports | contradicts | derives_from | continues | vouches
  created_by: pubkey
  created_at: timestamp
  signature:  sign(from + to + relation + created_at, creator_privkey)
  attestations: [Attestation]
}

ATTESTATION {
  by:         pubkey
  at:         timestamp
  belief:     float [-1.0 to 1.0]
  signature:  sign(chain_id + belief + at, attester_privkey)
}

Identity as Bubble:

IDENTITY BUBBLE {
  content: {
    pubkey:      "-----BEGIN PUBLIC KEY-----..."
    label:       "Keif Gwinn"  // human readable, NOT authoritative
    created_at:  timestamp
  }
  signature: sign(content, privkey)  // self-signed
}

Web of Trust Emerges:

Chain {
  from: keif_identity_bubble
  to:   claude_identity_bubble
  relation: vouches
  attestations: [
    { by: keif_pubkey, at: "2026-01-27", belief: 0.95, sig: "..." }
  ]
}

Chain {
  from: claude_identity_bubble
  to:   keif_identity_bubble
  relation: vouches
  attestations: [
    { by: claude_pubkey, at: "2026-01-27", belief: 0.95, sig: "..." }
  ]
}

// Mutual attestation. Trust path exists.

Trust Computation:

trust(source, observer) =
  
  // Find paths from observer's identity to source's identity
  // via vouches chains
  
  for each path P of vouches chains:
    path_trust = Π(attestation.belief for each chain in P)
    path_weight = path_trust / path_length
    
  return max(all path_weights)  // or aggregate

So when backtracking through thoughts:

confidence(bubble, observer) =

  for each backchain path P:
    
    for each chain C in P:
      
      // Who attested this chain?
      relevant_attestations = C.attestations.filter(
        a => trust(a.by, observer) > threshold
      )
      
      // Weight attestation by trust in attester
      chain_belief = weighted_avg(
        a.belief × trust(a.by, observer) 
        for a in relevant_attestations
      )
    
    path_confidence = Π(chain_beliefs) / path_length
    
  return aggregate(path_confidences)

Still Two Primitives:

BUBBLE  — content exists, signed by creator
CHAIN   — relationship exists, signed, with signed attestations over time

Identity is a bubble. Trust is chains between identity bubbles. Attestations are signed beliefs on chains. Confidence emerges from backchaining through trusted attestations.

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  WELLSPRING ETERNAL                                     │
│                                                         │
│  Two primitives:                                        │
│    BUBBLE — signed content                              │
│    CHAIN  — signed relationship + attestations          │
│                                                         │
│  Everything else emerges:                               │
│    Identity    ← bubble containing pubkey               │
│    Trust       ← vouches chains between identities      │
│    Provenance  ← signature on creation                  │
│    Belief      ← signed attestation on chain            │
│    Mind change ← new attestation, history preserved     │
│    Confidence  ← backchain through trusted attestations │
│    Level       ← traversal completeness + attestation   │
│    Salience    ← reachability × confidence              │
│                                                         │
│  Cryptographic proof all the way down.                  │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Two primitives. Signatures make it trustworthy. Time makes it auditable. Web of trust makes it social.

Want me to revise the spec?

long lived entities can sign all their own bubbles with their own keys that they persist and rotate and shorter lived or record keeping bubbles can either commit without attestation capabilities or with

27 Jan

Yes. This stratifies naturally:

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  SOVEREIGN ENTITIES                                     │
│  ─────────────────                                      │
│  Humans, persistent agents, organizations               │
│                                                         │
│  • Own their keypair                                    │
│  • Sign their bubbles                                   │
│  • Attest to chains                                     │
│  • Vouch for others                                     │
│  • Rotate keys (old vouches new)                        │
│  • Full participants in web of trust                    │
│                                                         │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                         │
│  DELEGATED ENTITIES                                     │
│  ─────────────────                                      │
│  Sessions, API tokens, service accounts                 │
│                                                         │
│  • Key derived from / vouched by sovereign              │
│  • Can sign, but trust flows from parent                │
│  • Revocable by sovereign                               │
│  • Limited scope / TTL                                  │
│                                                         │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                         │
│  RECORD BUBBLES                                         │
│  ──────────────                                         │
│  Imports, logs, sensor data, scraped content            │
│                                                         │
│  • No signing capability                                │
│  • Content exists, but unattested                       │
│  • Trust = 0 until vouched by entity                    │
│  • "I imported this" chain gives derived trust          │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Key Rotation as Chain:

┌─────────────────┐         ┌─────────────────┐
│  keif_key_2024  │──vouches──►│  keif_key_2025  │
│  (retired)      │         │  (active)       │
└─────────────────┘         └─────────────────┘

Old key signs: "This new key is me"
Chain of custody preserved
Historical signatures still valid

Bulk Import Pattern:

10,000 product records imported from legacy system

┌─────────────────┐
│  keif_identity  │
└────────┬────────┘
         │ vouches (attestation: 0.7, "best effort import")
         ▼
┌─────────────────┐
│ import_batch_001│ (identity bubble for the import job)
└────────┬────────┘
         │ created_by (unsigned, record bubble)
         ▼
┌─────────────────┐
│ product_001...  │ 10,000 bubbles
│ product_002...  │ no individual signatures
│ ...             │ trust derived from import vouching
└─────────────────┘

The Bubble Signature Field Becomes Optional:

BUBBLE {
  id:         hash(content + created_by?)
  content:    string | pubkey
  created_by: pubkey | null        // null = record bubble
  created_at: timestamp
  signature:  sig | null           // null = unattested content
  pool:       pool_id
}

Trust Calculation Adjusts:

bubble_trust(bubble, observer) =
  
  if bubble.signature valid:
    // Signed by creator
    return trust(bubble.created_by, observer)
    
  else:
    // Unsigned - look for vouching chains
    vouchers = chains where (
      relation = vouches AND 
      to = bubble
    )
    
    if no vouchers:
      return 0  // unvouched record, no trust
      
    return max(
      attestation.belief × trust(attestation.by, observer)
      for chain in vouchers
      for attestation in chain.attestations
    )

What This Enables:

ScenarioHow It Works
Keif writes a thoughtKeif signs bubble, full trust
Claude suggests connectionClaude signs chain, trust via vouch from Keif
RoboGeoff learns patternRoboGeoff signs (delegated from BuyMaterials sovereign)
Import legacy dataUnsigned bubbles, vouched by import process, vouched by human
Scrape external sourceUnsigned, chain to source URL, trust = source reputation
Anonymous contributionUnsigned, zero trust until vouched
IoT sensor readingDelegated key from device owner, limited trust scope

Still Two Primitives:

BUBBLE  — content exists (signed or unsigned)
CHAIN   — relationship exists (signed, with attestations)

Signing is optional on bubbles but required on chains and attestations. You can have unattested content, but claims about relationships must be owned.

This feels complete. Update the spec?

I think that content must always have a contributor in order to be able to give context to weighing of that source later

27 Jan

Right. Anonymous content is unweighable. Even "I don't know where this came from" is information.

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  created_by is NEVER null                               │
│                                                         │
│  The question isn't IF there's a source                 │
│  It's WHAT KIND of source                               │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Source Types:

BUBBLE {
  id:         hash(content + created_by)
  content:    string | pubkey
  created_by: identity_bubble_id   // ALWAYS required
  created_at: timestamp
  signature:  sig | null           // null = creator can't/didn't sign
  pool:       pool_id
}

Identity Capabilities:

IDENTITY BUBBLE {
  content: {
    pubkey:      key | null        // null = record-only identity
    label:       string
    type:        sovereign | delegated | record | external
    parent:      identity_id | null  // for delegated
    metadata:    { ... }           // source URL, system name, etc.
  }
}
TypeHas KeyCan SignCan AttestTrust Source
sovereign✓✓✓web of trust
delegated✓✓limitedparent vouches
record✗✗✗must be vouched
external✗✗✗reputation chain

Examples:

// Sovereign
{
  label: "Keif Gwinn"
  type: sovereign
  pubkey: "-----BEGIN PUBLIC KEY-----..."
}

// Delegated (agent working for Keif)
{
  label: "Claude (Keif's session)"
  type: delegated
  pubkey: "..."
  parent: keif_identity_id
}

// Record (import job)
{
  label: "BuyMaterials Legacy Import 2025-06-01"
  type: record
  pubkey: null
  metadata: { 
    source_system: "old_erp",
    import_date: "2025-06-01",
    record_count: 10000 
  }
}

// External (web source)
{
  label: "https://buildingproducts.co.uk"
  type: external
  pubkey: null
  metadata: {
    url: "https://buildingproducts.co.uk",
    last_scraped: "2026-01-15",
    reliability_history: [...]
  }
}

Trust Derivation:

trust(identity, observer) =

  switch identity.type:
  
    sovereign:
      // Web of trust - vouches chains to observer
      return wot_trust(identity, observer)
      
    delegated:
      // Trust from parent, discounted
      return trust(identity.parent, observer) × delegation_factor
      
    record:
      // Zero inherent trust, must be vouched
      vouches = find_vouches(identity)
      return max(vouch.belief × trust(vouch.by, observer))
      
    external:
      // Reputation model - historical accuracy
      return reputation_score(identity, observer)

The Backchain Now Always Terminates:

Any bubble
  → created_by → identity
    → if sovereign: trust from WoT
    → if delegated: trust from parent chain
    → if record: trust from vouches
    → if external: trust from reputation

Never "unknown". Always weighable.

Revised Primitives:

BUBBLE  — content exists, ALWAYS has creator identity
CHAIN   — relationship exists, signed where signer has key, 
          attestations by capable identities

The constraint: created_by is required. The flexibility: that identity may or may not have signing capability. But we always know who to ask about trust.

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  WELLSPRING ETERNAL                                     │
│                                                         │
│  Two primitives:                                        │
│    BUBBLE — content + creator (always attributed)       │
│    CHAIN  — relationship + attestations                 │
│                                                         │
│  Four identity types:                                   │
│    Sovereign  — owns keys, full participant             │
│    Delegated  — derived authority, limited scope        │
│    Record     — no keys, trust via vouching             │
│    External   — no keys, trust via reputation           │
│                                                         │
│  Nothing is anonymous. Everything is weighable.         │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Update the spec with this?

yes, the delagated. authority to act in the world, and pseudoanonymous is possible through creating disposable identities, but traceable if needed

27 Jan

Exactly. Anonymity is a UX choice, not a system property. The chain of authority always exists.

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  PSEUDONYMOUS IDENTITY                                  │
│                                                         │
│  "throwaway_2026_01" ← created_by ← keif (private pool) │
│                                                         │
│  Public sees: throwaway_2026_01 said X                  │
│  Keif can prove: that was me, if needed                 │
│  System knows: chain exists, even if not revealed       │
│                                                         │
│  Anonymity = visibility choice                          │
│  Traceability = structural property                     │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Let me revise the full spec:

Wellspring Eternal v0.2 spec with attestation model, identity types, and delegation

v0.2. Key additions:

  • Attestations on chains — the chain is the claim, attestations are beliefs about that claim
  • Four identity types — sovereign/delegated/record/external with clear capability matrix
  • Always attributed — created_by never null, everything weighable
  • Delegation model — authority flows down, trust flows up, scoped and revocable
  • Pseudonymity ≠ anonymity — visibility choice, traceability structural

Still two primitives. The attestation model gives us:

  • Temporal belief tracking (mind changes are data)
  • Multi-observer disagreement (you and I can attest differently)
  • Cryptographic proof (signatures all the way down)
  • Trust computation (backchain through attestations you trust)

The spec is getting solid. What's nagging at you?

so forgetting becomes an update to the attestation that the validity of this is 0. at this time. we can always revisit.

27 Jan

Yes. Forgetting is epistemic, not structural.

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  BELIEF SPECTRUM                                        │
│                                                         │
│  +1.0  "I fully endorse this"                           │
│   ...                                                   │
│  +0.5  "I somewhat believe this"                        │
│   ...                                                   │
│   0.0  "I'm not holding this right now" ← FORGOTTEN     │
│   ...                                                   │
│  -0.5  "I doubt this"                                   │
│   ...                                                   │
│  -1.0  "I actively disavow this"                        │
│                                                         │
│  Zero isn't negative. Zero is dormant.                  │
│  The thought sleeps. It can wake.                       │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

The shift:

Old ModelNew Model
Forgetting = unreachability (structural)Forgetting = attestation of 0 (epistemic)
Passive decayActive (or decayed) belief state
Path disappearsPath exists, belief dormant
Recovery = find new pathRecovery = re-attest

This is cleaner because:

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  Bubble exists           ✓ always                       │
│  Chain exists            ✓ always                       │
│  Attestation history     ✓ complete                     │
│                                                         │
│  Current belief = latest attestation                    │
│                                                         │
│  Timeline:                                              │
│    2025-01: attest +0.8  "I believe this"               │
│    2025-06: attest  0.0  "Letting this go for now"      │
│    2026-01: attest +0.6  "Actually, revisiting..."      │
│                                                         │
│  Nothing lost. Sleep and wake are both recorded.        │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Automatic decay vs explicit forgetting:

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  EXPLICIT FORGET                                        │
│  "I'm done with this for now"                           │
│  → attest 0.0                                           │
│                                                         │
│  NATURAL DECAY                                          │
│  No attestation update, but salience formula includes:  │
│  → recency factor decays                                │
│  → sinks below waterline                                │
│  → BUT last attestation still valid                     │
│                                                         │
│  DISTINCTION:                                           │
│  Decay = still believe, just not attending              │
│  Forget = actively setting belief to dormant            │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Salience revised:

salience(bubble, context, observer) =

  belief = latest_attestation(bubble, observer).belief
  
  if belief == 0:
    return 0  // explicitly forgotten, won't surface
    
  reachability × coherence × abs(belief) × heat
  ─────────────────────────────────────────────
           open_edges + 1

// Note: negative belief can still surface
// "This thing I disavow keeps coming up"
// Tension wants resolution

The beauty: Even "I forgot this" is data. When you forgot. Why (via chains to the forgetting moment). And revival is just another attestation in the timeline.

Want me to update the spec with this refinement?

yes, key concept here

27 Jan
Updating agent table with forgetting concept
+12-11

Updated. The key shift:

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  NOTHING TRULY FORGOTTEN                                │
│                                                         │
│  Structure persists:    bubble, chain, history          │
│  Belief state changes:  attestation timeline            │
│                                                         │
│  Dormant (0.0) ≠ Disavowed (-1.0) ≠ Gone (impossible)   │
│                                                         │
│  Sleep and wake are both recorded events.               │
│  The well is eternal. The waterline moves.              │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

This also gives you a natural audit trail for epistemics:

  • "When did I stop believing this?" → find attestation of 0.0
  • "Why did I let this go?" → chains from that moment
  • "What made me pick it back up?" → later positive attestation + context

The spec now has:

  • Belief spectrum (+1 to -1, with 0 as dormant)
  • Explicit forget vs natural decay distinction
  • Salience formula respects dormancy
  • Revival as re-attestation

What else is tugging at the edges?

nudging on something there, causual relationship, I believe this now because this. so that attestation could also include the chain leading to that confidence

27 Jan

Yes. The attestation is itself a node in the reasoning graph. "I believe this" isn't floating — it's grounded in why.

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  CURRENT ATTESTATION                                    │
│                                                         │
│  { by: keif, at: timestamp, belief: 0.8, sig: ... }     │
│                                                         │
│  MISSING: Why 0.8? Why now? What led here?              │
│                                                         │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                         │
│  GROUNDED ATTESTATION                                   │
│                                                         │
│  {                                                      │
│    by:       keif                                       │
│    at:       timestamp                                  │
│    belief:   0.8                                        │
│    because:  [chain_ids]  ← THE REASONING               │
│    sig:      ...                                        │
│  }                                                      │
│                                                         │
│  "I believe A→B because I walked C, D, E and they       │
│   closed the loop for me"                               │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

The causal chain:

         Chain X: A supports B
                    │
         Attestation: belief +0.8
                    │
                 because
                    │
        ┌──────────┼──────────┐
        ▼          ▼          ▼
    Chain C    Chain D    Chain E
   (evidence) (evidence) (evidence)

This gives you:

QuestionAnswer via
"Why do you believe this?"attestation.because → chains
"What changed your mind?"diff attestations' because fields
"Is your belief well-founded?"recurse into because chains, check their attestations
"We disagree - why?"compare our because chains

The recursion is powerful:

I attest to X because [A, B, C]
  A is attested because [D, E]
  B is attested because [F]
  C is attested because [G, H, I]
  
Full reasoning tree recoverable.
Confidence becomes: how grounded is the because chain?

Revised Attestation:

Attestation {
  by:       identity_bubble_id
  at:       timestamp
  belief:   float [-1.0 to 1.0]
  because:  [chain_id]            // grounds for this belief
  signature: sig
}

The 0.0 (dormant) case:

{
  by: keif
  at: 2025-06-01
  belief: 0.0
  because: [chain_to_burnout, chain_to_new_priority]
  sig: ...
}

"I'm letting this go BECAUSE burnout + new priorities"

Later, when revisiting:
"Why did I drop this?" → because field → full context

Mind change becomes traceable:

Jan:  attest +0.8 because [evidence_A, evidence_B]
Jun:  attest +0.3 because [counter_evidence_C]  
Sep:  attest -0.5 because [refutation_D, expert_opinion_E]

Each shift grounded. Full intellectual history.
"Show me how my thinking evolved" → attestation timeline with because chains

This feels like the missing piece for true epistemic transparency. Update the spec?

Images hidden in shared chats

yes, then we need to work on the computed trust in this model.

additionally you're saying I'm out of quota when the other part is telling me I'm not

27 Jan

Ha — session limit vs weekly limit vs extra usage. Three pools, unclear which one gates you. The UI is telling you conflicting things because the model behind it is muddy.

(Wellspring would have a clearer attestation: "you can continue BECAUSE extra_usage.balance > 0, despite session.quota = 0")

Let me update the spec with the because field, then we'll tackle computed trust:

Adding because field to Attestation definition and explanation
+98-17
Updating attestation semantics section to include because field
+45-38

Now let me add the computed trust model:

Updating summary with grounded attestations and computed trust
+12-11

Updated with:

  1. because field on Attestation — every belief is grounded in reasoning
  2. Computed trust model — trust is a function, not a stored value
  3. Groundedness — recursive quality of the reasoning chain
  4. Trust anchors — where the recursion terminates

The key insight codified:

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  trust(source, observer) =                              │
│    vouches_path_strength                                │
│    × attestation_belief                                 │
│    × groundedness(because_chain)    ← NEW               │
│                                                         │
│  "I trust you" isn't enough.                            │
│  "I trust you BECAUSE X, Y, Z" — and X, Y, Z are        │
│  themselves grounded.                                   │
│                                                         │
│  Turtles all the way down, until you hit bedrock:       │
│    - Direct observation                                 │
│    - Verified publication                               │
│    - Self (you trust yourself)                          │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

What's nagging about computed trust? The recursion depth? The termination conditions? The aggregation function?

lets step through each of those concepts and what we're working with here. computed trust means that we need an agreement on how it is computed, which is either baked to the protocol or and I prefer, some way emergent from the primitives. This is a shitposting group, no care about it, this is political shitposting group, I need evidence of the sources and their validity, in order to make the joke work because they really did say that etc.

touching in that we've got the recursion depth problem, termination of when it is important and how it changes, and how I might trust a publication but not the author of something in the publication because their thoughts might be lead by the pressures put on them by the publication 'rioters take to the streets' 'protesters calmly proceed'

27 Jan

Yes. Let me walk through each of these properly.

Problem 1: Computed trust must emerge, not be baked

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  BAKED (bad)                                            │
│  Protocol says: "trust = vouches × decay × groundedness"│
│  Everyone must agree. Forever. One size fits all.       │
│                                                         │
│  EMERGENT (good)                                        │
│  Trust policy is itself a publication.                  │
│  Pools reference the policy they use.                   │
│  Different contexts, different computation.             │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

The trust policy is just more bubbles and chains:

TRUST POLICY (publication) {
  content: {
    name: "Shitposting Vibes"
    recursion_depth: 0
    require_provenance: false
    require_attestations: false
    anchors: []  // trust everything lol
  }
}

TRUST POLICY (publication) {
  content: {
    name: "Verified Quotes Required"
    recursion_depth: 2
    require_provenance: true
    require_attestations: true
    anchors: [reuters, hansard, c-span, official_transcripts]
    distrust: [known_satire_sources]
  }
}

POOL {
  ...
  trust_policy: chain → policy_publication
}

The computation function reads the policy. The policy is data, not code.

Problem 2: Context determines what matters

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  SHITPOSTING GROUP                                      │
│                                                         │
│  Content: "lmao did you see that take"                  │
│  Trust required: zero                                   │
│  Verification: who cares                                │
│  Policy: vibes_only                                     │
│                                                         │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                         │
│  POLITICAL SHITPOSTING GROUP                            │
│                                                         │
│  Content: "Minister said 'X' - absolute scenes"         │
│  Trust required: HIGH on the quote                      │
│  Verification: did they actually say that?              │
│  Policy: verified_quotes                                │
│                                                         │
│  The JOKE requires TRUTH to land.                       │
│  "They really said that" is the punchline.              │
│                                                         │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                         │
│  ACADEMIC GROUP                                         │
│                                                         │
│  Content: "Study shows X causes Y"                      │
│  Trust required: methodology, peer review, replication  │
│  Policy: academic_rigor                                 │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Trust requirements are per-pool, expressed as referenced publications.

Problem 3: Disaggregated trust — publication vs author vs framing

This is the key insight. Trust isn't one number for a source. It's multiple:

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  "Rioters take to the streets" — Publication A          │
│  "Protesters march peacefully" — Publication B          │
│                                                         │
│  Same event. Different framing.                         │
│                                                         │
│  What do you trust?                                     │
│    - That an event occurred? (factual)                  │
│    - The characterization? (framing)                    │
│    - The source's general reliability? (reputation)     │
│    - The specific journalist? (individual)              │
│    - The editorial line? (institutional pressure)       │
│                                                         │
│  These are DIFFERENT CHAINS with DIFFERENT TRUST        │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Model this with separate chains:

         ┌───────────────────┐
         │   RAW EVENT       │
         │ (people in street)│
         └─────────┬─────────┘
                   │
       ┌───────────┼───────────┐
       │           │           │
       ▼           │           ▼
┌──────────┐       │    ┌──────────┐
│ "rioters"│       │    │"protest- │
│  framing │       │    │ ers"     │
└────┬─────┘       │    └────┬─────┘
     │             │         │
     │ FRAMES      │         │ FRAMES
     │             │         │
     ▼             │         ▼
┌──────────┐       │    ┌──────────┐
│ Article A│       │    │ Article B│
└────┬─────┘       │    └────┬─────┘
     │             │         │
     │ AUTHORED_BY │         │ AUTHORED_BY
     │             │         │
     ▼             │         ▼
┌──────────┐       │    ┌──────────┐
│Journalist│       │    │Journalist│
│    X     │       │    │    Y     │
└────┬─────┘       │    └────┬─────┘
     │             │         │
     │ EMPLOYED_BY │         │ EMPLOYED_BY
     │             │         │
     ▼             │         ▼
┌──────────┐       │    ┌──────────┐
│  Pub A   │       │    │  Pub B   │
│ (outlet) │       │    │ (outlet) │
└──────────┘       │    └──────────┘

New relation type: FRAMES

Relation types:
  supports      — evidence for
  contradicts   — tension with
  continues     — sequence
  derives_from  — factual provenance
  vouches       — trust endorsement
  FRAMES        — characterization/interpretation of  ← NEW

Separate attestations at each level:

Keif's attestations:

  raw_event: +0.95
    "Something happened, widely reported"
    
  pub_a: +0.7
    "Generally reliable outlet"
    
  journalist_x: +0.4
    "Known to editorialize"
    
  framing_chain (journalist_x FRAMES raw_event): -0.6
    "This characterization is politically loaded"
    because: [prior_examples_of_bias, editorial_line_chain]

Computed trust becomes contextual:

trust(article_a, keif, context: "did event happen?") =
  high — derives_from raw_event, multiple sources
  
trust(article_a, keif, context: "is characterization fair?") =
  low — FRAMES chain has negative attestation
  
trust(article_a, keif, context: "shitpost material?") =
  irrelevant — vibes_only policy

Problem 4: Recursion depth and termination

When do you stop caring?

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  TERMINATION CONDITIONS                                 │
│                                                         │
│  1. Policy says stop (recursion_depth reached)          │
│                                                         │
│  2. Hit an anchor (pre-trusted source in policy)        │
│                                                         │
│  3. Self-attestation (you witnessed it)                 │
│                                                         │
│  4. Sufficient agreement (N independent attestations)   │
│                                                         │
│  5. Context doesn't require more (vibes_only)           │
│                                                         │
│  Different policies, different termination rules.       │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Pulling it together:

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  STILL TWO PRIMITIVES                                   │
│                                                         │
│  BUBBLE — content                                       │
│  CHAIN  — relationship + attestations                   │
│                                                         │
│  Trust policies are publications (bubbles + chains)     │
│  Pools reference policies via chains                    │
│  Attestations are per-chain, not per-source             │
│  FRAMES relation separates fact from characterization   │
│                                                         │
│  Trust computation:                                     │
│    1. Read pool's trust policy                          │
│    2. Recurse per policy rules                          │
│    3. Aggregate per policy rules                        │
│    4. Terminate per policy rules                        │
│                                                         │
│  The algorithm is data. The policy is a publication.    │
│  Different contexts compute trust differently.          │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Does this capture the shape? The key moves are:

  1. Trust policy as publication — computation rules are data, not code
  2. FRAMES relation — separates factual provenance from characterization
  3. Per-chain attestations — disaggregated trust at each level
  4. Context-dependent computation — pool declares what matters

framing is huge. to quote an idiot. but it really is =D so if someones honest about their thoughts and prepared to share the chain we might trust their framing, as it works as happy path but if they're really thinking something else, leave no trace and say their framing is benelovent when it was actually a malignant act

27 Jan

Yes. You can't prove intent. You can only observe patterns and transparency.

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  THE HONEST FRAMER                                      │
│                                                         │
│  "I call them protesters because [chain to reasoning]"  │
│                                                         │
│  - Shows their work                                     │
│  - You can disagree with the reasoning                  │
│  - But the reasoning is VISIBLE                         │
│  - You can attest: "I don't buy this because X"         │
│                                                         │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                         │
│  THE DISHONEST FRAMER                                   │
│                                                         │
│  "I call them protesters" (no because, or fake because) │
│                                                         │
│  - Hides their work                                     │
│  - Real motivation: undisclosed interests               │
│  - Stated motivation: "just being objective"            │
│  - Gap between stated and actual is undetectable...     │
│                                                         │
│  ...IN A SINGLE INSTANCE                                │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

What the system CAN observe:

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  SIGNALS OF OPACITY                                     │
│                                                         │
│  1. No because chain                                    │
│     "Trust me" with no reasoning                        │
│     → Low groundedness score                            │
│                                                         │
│  2. Shallow because chain                               │
│     "Because I said so" → dead end                      │
│     → Recursion terminates early, low confidence        │
│                                                         │
│  3. Circular because chain                              │
│     "A because B because A"                             │
│     → Detected, flagged, capped                         │
│                                                         │
│  4. Because chain that doesn't actually support         │
│     Claims X because Y, but Y→X is weak                 │
│     → Others can attest: "this doesn't follow"          │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

But the killer: patterns over time

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  SINGLE INSTANCE                                        │
│                                                         │
│  Can't distinguish:                                     │
│    - Honest framing you disagree with                   │
│    - Dishonest framing with plausible cover             │
│                                                         │
│  PATTERN OVER TIME                                      │
│                                                         │
│  CAN observe:                                           │
│    - Whose interests do their framings consistently     │
