│    - Inference across domains                           │
│                                                         │
│  Reality:                                               │
│    - Who creates the ontology? (academics, slowly)      │
│    - Who tags the data? (no one, too tedious)           │
│    - Who maintains it? (it rots)                        │
│                                                         │
│  Result: Beautiful theory. Empty graphs.                │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

The Wellspring flip:

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  OLD: Top-down ontology → beg for data                  │
│                                                         │
│  Academic: "Here's the food ontology with 47 classes"   │
│  User: "I'm not tagging my lunch with rdfs:subClassOf"  │
│  Result: Dead.                                          │
│                                                         │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                                         │
│  NEW: Behavior → agent proposes → human attests         │
│                                                         │
│  Keif: *chooses Nandos 4 times in 6 weeks*              │
│  Agent: "You seem to enjoy spicy food. True?"           │
│  Keif: attests +1.0 on keif/aspect:enjoys-spicy         │
│                                                         │
│  Keif: *always picks places with parking*               │
│  Agent: "Easy parking matters to you. True?"            │
│  Keif: attests +0.8 on keif/aspect:values-parking       │
│        because: [kids, car-seats, hassle]               │
│                                                         │
│  Keif: *rejects agent's inference*                      │
│  Agent: "You prefer chains over independents?"          │
│  Keif: attests -0.5, because: [coincidence, not-pattern]│
│                                                         │
│  THE ONTOLOGY EMERGES FROM BEHAVIOR + ATTESTATION.      │
│  Not from a committee.                                  │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

The attestation feedback loop:

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  1. OBSERVE                                             │
│     Agent watches: choices, patterns, timing            │
│                                                         │
│  2. INFER                                               │
│     Agent proposes: "This looks like aspect X"          │
│                                                         │
│  3. PROPOSE                                             │
│     Agent creates: CHAIN: keif → might_have →           │
│                          aspect:enjoys-spicy            │
│       attestation: { by: agent, +0.7,                   │
│                      because: [nandos_4x, chose_hot] }  │
│                                                         │
│  4. SURFACE                                             │
│     Agent asks: "Do you recognise this as true?"        │
│                                                         │
│  5. ATTEST                                              │
│     Keif responds:                                      │
│       YES: { by: keif, +1.0, because: [accurate] }      │
│       NO:  { by: keif, -0.5, because: [correlation_not  │
│             _causation, actually_went_for_kids] }       │
│       REFINE: { by: keif, +0.6, because: [partially,    │
│                 more_about_peri_peri_than_general] }    │
│                                                         │
│  6. LEARN                                               │
│     Agent updates model based on keif's attestation     │
│     Better proposals next time                          │
│                                                         │
│  7. REPEAT                                              │
│     Ontology grows organically from the bottom up       │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Agent proposal as chain:

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  BUBBLE: inference:keif-spicy-2026-01                   │
│    type: agent_inference                                │
│    subject: keif                                        │
│    proposed_aspect: enjoys-spicy                        │
│    confidence: 0.7                                      │
│    evidence: [choice:nandos-jan3, choice:nandos-jan15,  │
│               choice:nandos-jan22, order:extra-hot-x3]  │
│                                                         │
│  CHAIN: inference:keif-spicy →                          │
│         proposes → keif/aspect:enjoys-spicy             │
│    attestation: { by: agent, +0.7 }                     │
│                                                         │
│  HUMAN RESPONSE (one of):                               │
│                                                         │
│  CHAIN: keif/aspect:enjoys-spicy → recognised_by → keif │
│    attestation: { by: keif, +1.0,                       │
│                   because: [inference:keif-spicy] }     │
│    "Yes, agent got it right"                            │
│                                                         │
│  CHAIN: inference:keif-spicy → rejected_by → keif       │
│    attestation: { by: keif, -0.8,                       │
│                   because: [kids-drove-choice,          │
│                             not-about-spicy] }          │
│    "No, and here's why you're wrong"                    │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

The WHY matters:

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  Agent proposes: keif/aspect:prefers-chains             │
│  Evidence: [nandos, wagamama, pizza-express]            │
│                                                         │
│  Keif rejects: -0.7                                     │
│  Because: [                                             │
│    keif/thought:chains-are-consistent,                  │
│    keif/thought:consistency-matters-with-kids,          │
│    keif/thought:not-about-chain-vs-indie,               │
│    keif/aspect:predictability-for-family   ← THE REAL  │
│  ]                                                      │
│                                                         │
│  Agent learns:                                          │
│    - "prefers-chains" was wrong framing                 │
│    - "predictability-for-family" is actual aspect       │
│    - Correlates with: has-children, time-pressure       │
│                                                         │
│  NEXT INFERENCE:                                        │
│    When keif is solo (no kids), suggest independents    │
│    When keif has kids, suggest predictable places       │
│                                                         │
│  The rejection + because TAUGHT the agent.              │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Aspect hierarchy emerges:

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  OBSERVED:                                              │
│    keif/aspect:enjoys-spicy                             │
│    keif/aspect:likes-peri-peri                          │
│    keif/aspect:enjoys-thai-heat                         │
│                                                         │
│  AGENT PROPOSES:                                        │
│    CHAIN: likes-peri-peri → instance_of → enjoys-spicy  │
│    CHAIN: enjoys-thai-heat → instance_of → enjoys-spicy │
│                                                         │
│  KEIF ATTESTS:                                          │
│    +1.0 on peri-peri → enjoys-spicy                     │
│    +0.5 on thai-heat → enjoys-spicy                     │
│      because: [different-kind-of-heat,                  │
│                thai-is-more-aromatic]                   │
│                                                         │
│  ONTOLOGY EMERGES:                                      │
│                                                         │
│    enjoys-spicy                                         │
│      ├── likes-peri-peri (+1.0, clear instance)         │
│      └── enjoys-thai-heat (+0.5, partial, different)    │
│                                                         │
│  This is OWL rdfs:subClassOf built from behavior,       │
│  not from academic decree.                              │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Shared ontology through consensus:

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  UNIVERSAL ASPECTS (proposed, attested, adopted)        │
│                                                         │
│  Agent observes across many users:                      │
│    "kid-friendly" appears in 80% of family pools        │
│                                                         │
│  Agent proposes:                                        │
│    BUBBLE: universal/aspect:kid-friendly                │
│    CHAIN: → proposed_for → pool:wellspring-aspects      │
│    attestation: { by: agent, +0.9,                      │
│                   because: [observed-in-N-pools] }      │
│                                                         │
│  Users attest:                                          │
│    keif: +1.0, because: [matches-my-usage]              │
│    sarah: +1.0                                          │
│    mike: +0.8, because: [would-phrase-differently]      │
│    jules: +1.0                                          │
│                                                         │
│  Threshold reached → becomes universal aspect           │
│  Now available for everyone to use                      │
│  Still refines based on ongoing attestation             │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

The AllegroGraph / Oxford Semantic connection:

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  WELLSPRING = Data creation layer                       │
│               (behavior → proposal → attestation)       │
│                                                         │
│  SEMANTIC REASONING = Query layer                       │
│               (inference over the graph)                │
│                                                         │
│  Once you have the data:                                │
│                                                         │
│    QUERY: "Find restaurants that satisfy keif's         │
│            constraint:family-friendly AND               │
│            sarah's constraint:vegetarian AND            │
│            within 10 miles AND                          │
│            not visited in 30 days"                      │
│                                                         │
│    INFERENCE: "keif likes peri-peri, peri-peri is       │
│                instance_of spicy, therefore keif        │
│                might like other spicy options"          │
│                                                         │
│    REASONING: "sarah attested +1.0 on wagamama via      │
│                vegetarian-options, wagamama has         │
│                same-cuisine-as ramen-house, therefore   │
│                sarah might like ramen-house via         │
│                vegetarian-options"                      │
│                                                         │
│  The semantic web WORKS when you have the data.         │
│  Wellspring creates the data.                           │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

The moat:

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  AllegroGraph / Oxford Semantic:                        │
│    - Powerful reasoning engines                         │
│    - No data creation story                             │
│    - Enterprise focus (expensive, complex)              │
│    - "Bring your ontology and data"                     │
│                                                         │
│  Wellspring:                                            │
│    - Data EMERGES from behavior                         │
│    - Ontology EMERGES from attestation                  │
│    - Consumer focus (personal, social)                  │
│    - "Just live your life, we'll build the graph"       │
│                                                         │
│  They need us more than we need them.                   │
│                                                         │
│  Once Wellspring has rich behavioral data:              │
│    - Plug in any reasoning engine                       │
│    - Or build native inference                          │
│    - The data is the moat, not the query engine         │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

The full loop:

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  BEHAVIOR                                               │
│    │                                                    │
│    │ observed by                                        │
│    ▼                                                    │
│  AGENT INFERENCE                                        │
│    │                                                    │
│    │ proposes                                           │
│    ▼                                                    │
│  ASPECT (candidate)                                     │
│    │                                                    │
│    │ surfaced to                                        │
│    ▼                                                    │
│  HUMAN ATTESTATION                                      │
│    │ (+1, -1, refined, with BECAUSE)                    │
│    │                                                    │
│    │ confirms/refines                                   │
│    ▼                                                    │
│  ASPECT (validated)                                     │
│    │                                                    │
│    │ enables                                            │
│    ▼                                                    │
│  SEMANTIC REASONING                                     │
│    │                                                    │
│    │ improves                                           │
│    ▼                                                    │
│  PREDICTIONS / RECOMMENDATIONS                          │
│    │                                                    │
│    │ drives                                             │
│    ▼                                                    │
│  BEHAVIOR (better informed)                             │
│    │                                                    │
│    └──────────── loops back ────────────────────────────│
│                                                         │
│  Virtuous cycle. Data creates itself.                   │
│  Human stays in the loop (attestation).                 │
│  Ontology emerges, not imposed.                         │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Add to spec:

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                         │
│  EMERGENT ONTOLOGY                                      │
│                                                         │
│  Principles:                                            │
│    1. Aspects proposed by agent, attested by human      │
│    2. Hierarchy emerges from instance_of attestations   │
│    3. Universal aspects emerge from cross-user patterns │
│    4. Rejection + because teaches the agent             │
│    5. Ontology is data, not schema                      │
│    6. Can export to OWL/RDF for external reasoning      │
│                                                         │
│  Agent proposals are ALWAYS:                            │
│    - Marked as agent-proposed                           │
│    - Surfaced for human review                          │
│    - Not trusted until attested                         │
│    - Learning from rejection as much as acceptance      │
│                                                         │
│  The WHY (because chain) is first-class:                │
│    - Acceptance because: [evidence that worked]         │
│    - Rejection because: [why the inference was wrong]   │
│    - Refinement because: [what's actually true]         │
│                                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

The semantic web's grave error was assuming humans would do the work. Wellspring's insight: the agent does the work, humans just say yes/no/why. That's sustainable. That's how you get a living ontology.

New in v0.3:

AdditionWhat It Is
Bush's MemexHistorical grounding — we're completing an 80-year vision
TrailsFirst-class named paths, shareable, multi-master
Browser ExtensionAutomated trail capture from browsing behavior
Sync as AttestationSNAP-inspired, no separate protocol layer — chains all the way down
Pool ModelUniversal primitive — your pod IS a pool, federation via attestation
Aspect-Based AttestationsDecomposed via field — the WHY is data, not metadata
Emergent OntologyAgent proposes, human attests, because chains teach
WOT IntegrationGroup consensus as Wellspring application

The key insight crystallised:

Semantic Web died on data entry.
Wellspring: behavior → agent proposes → human attests → ontology grows.
The human just says yes/no/refine + WHY.
That's sustainable.

what else could we learn from OWL other than its heaviness

27 Jan

Good question. Let me actually dig into what OWL does well beyond being heavy.

Good question. Looking beyond the weight, OWL has several genuinely useful concepts we could adopt:

1. Property Characteristics (Relation Types)

OWL declares properties as transitive, symmetric, inverse, functional. We have some of this implicitly but could be explicit:

RELATION CHARACTERISTICS (could add to Wellspring)

Transitive:    part_of, ancestor_of, contains
               If A part_of B, B part_of C → A part_of C

Symmetric:     sibling_of, colleague_of, related_to
               If A sibling_of B → B sibling_of A

Inverse:       parent_of ↔ child_of, employs ↔ works_at
               If A parent_of B → B child_of A

Functional:    has_mother (exactly one value)
               If A has_mother B and A has_mother C → B = C

We currently have vouches, supports, derives_from but haven't declared their propagation characteristics formally.

2. Disjointness (Mutual Exclusion)

OWL can declare "Person and Company are disjoint" — nothing can be both. We could use this:

CHAIN: keif/constraint:vegetarian → disjoint_with → contains_meat
  // Anything attested as vegetarian CANNOT be attested as contains_meat
  // System catches contradiction automatically

Useful for catching inconsistencies in attestations.

3. Property Chains (Compositional Relations)

OWL can define: hasUncle = hasFather ∘ hasBrother. If you have chains A→B and B→C, infer A→C.

PROPERTY CHAIN:

lives_in_country = lives_in_city ∘ city_in_country

keif → lives_in → Manchester
Manchester → in_country → UK
∴ keif → lives_in_country → UK   (inferred)

This is powerful for automatic chain completion. We could declare these for inference without storing redundant chains.

4. Cardinality Constraints

OWL: "Person must have exactly 2 biological parents" or "Car must have at least 4 wheels"

CARDINALITY:

keif/constraint:vegetarian
  min_options: 1  // venue must have at least 1 veggie option
  
family-dinner
  max_cost_per_head: 25  // £25 cap

For WOT specifically, this is useful — "must have at least N options satisfying constraint."

5. Open World Assumption

OWL assumes absence of information ≠ false. This is philosophically correct and we're already doing it (attestation absent ≠ belief absent), but worth making explicit:

WELLSPRING: Open World

No attestation from keif on nandos
  ≠ keif believes 0.0 about nandos
  = keif hasn't expressed belief

This differs from closed-world databases where
  row absent = fact false

6. Equivalence (Same-As)

OWL: owl:sameAs for identity resolution. We started on this with resolves_to:

CHAIN: "Keef" → same_as → "Keif"
CHAIN: keif@gmail → same_as → keif@buymaterials
  // Different handles, same person
  // Trust transfers across equivalence

7. Class Intersection / Union

OWL can define "Father = Person AND Male AND hasChild". We could express:

keif/aspect:family-friendly =
  intersection_of:
    - kid-friendly
    - affordable
    - has-parking

// Satisfies family-friendly iff satisfies all three

What's Worth Adopting (Lightweight)

OWL ConceptWellspring AdoptionComplexity
Property characteristicsDeclare on relation typesLow
DisjointnessConstraint conflictsLow
Property chainsInference rulesMedium
CardinalityFor WOT constraintsLow
Open worldAlready implicit, documentNone
EquivalenceIdentity resolutionAlready started
Class expressionsAspect compositionMedium

What to Skip

  • Description logic formalism (computational cost, no value add)
  • XML/RDF syntax (unnecessary indirection)
  • Profiles/sublanguages (we want one simple thing)
  • Formal decidability guarantees (we're probabilistic anyway)

Concrete Addition to Spec?

We could add a section on Inference Rules that declares property characteristics and enables automatic chain completion:

RELATION: part_of
  characteristics: [transitive, antisymmetric]
  inverse: contains
  
RELATION: vouches
  characteristics: [non-transitive]  // explicit: trust doesn't auto-propagate
  // We COMPUTE trust, not INFER it

PROPERTY_CHAIN:
  works_at_company_in = works_at ∘ headquartered_in
  // keif works_at BuyMaterials, BuyMaterials headquartered_in UK
  // → keif works_at_company_in UK (inferred, not stored)

Want me to draft an "Inference and Constraints" section for v0.3?

yes I was already thinking about the issues of uniquness and constraints, so we do want all of those, lets look at class expressions in a bit more detail, and keep all responses short as we're in extra token time

27 Jan

OWL class expressions:

Intersection (AND)

Father = Person ∩ Male ∩ hasChild.some(Person)
// Must satisfy ALL conditions

Union (OR)

Parent = Mother ∪ Father
// Satisfies ANY condition

Complement (NOT)

NonVegetarian = ¬Vegetarian
// Everything NOT in the class

Wellspring translation:

ASPECT: family-friendly
  type: composite
  expression: intersection_of [kid-friendly, affordable, has-parking]
  // +1.0 on family-friendly requires +1.0 on ALL components

ASPECT: date-night-option  
  type: composite
  expression: union_of [romantic, upscale, has-bar]
  // +1.0 if ANY component is +1.0

CONSTRAINT: not-fast-food
  type: composite
  expression: complement_of [fast-food-chain]
  // +1.0 only if fast-food-chain is ≤0

The interesting bit: With aspects decomposed, we can COMPUTE composite satisfaction:

keif on nandos:
  kid-friendly: +0.9
  affordable: +0.8
  has-parking: -0.3

family-friendly (intersection) = min(0.9, 0.8, -0.3) = -0.3
// Fails on parking, whole composite fails

date-night (union) = max(romantic, upscale, bar) = ?
// Satisfies if ANY aspect hits

Question: Do we want min/max semantics (crisp) or weighted average (fuzzy)? For constraints, min makes sense (weakest link). For preferences, maybe weighted?

Want me to draft the full Inference & Constraints section now?

I like min/max and weighted/fuzzy. gotta have the concept of must

27 Jan

Right. Two modes:

COMPOSITE EXPRESSION

mode: must (min/max)
  intersection: min(components)  — weakest link breaks it
  union: max(components)         — best option carries it
  
  Use for: constraints, dealbreakers, requirements
  "Must have parking AND veggie options"

mode: prefer (weighted)
  intersection: weighted_avg(components)
  union: weighted_avg(components)  
  
  Use for: preferences, nice-to-haves
  "Prefer spicy, convenient, cheap"

Combined:

DECISION: friday-dinner

must:
  intersection_of: [everyone-can-eat, within-budget, someone-can-drive]
  // ALL required. Any -1.0 = veto entire option
  
prefer:
  weighted_of: [spicy: 0.5, kids-happy: 0.9, easy-parking: 0.3]
  // Averaged. Drives ranking among survivors

EVALUATION:
  1. Filter by must (min semantics, any fail = out)
  2. Rank by prefer (weighted avg of survivors)

This is exactly how humans actually decide. Hard requirements first, then optimize preferences among what's left.

Draft the full section?

yes

27 Jan

bash

cp /home/claude/inference-constraints-section.md /mnt/user-data/outputs/

Output

exit code 0

Done. Key points:

Must mode (min/max):

  • Intersection: weakest link breaks it
  • Union: best option carries it
  • For: constraints, dealbreakers

Prefer mode (weighted):

  • Weighted average across components
  • For: nice-to-haves, ranking

Decision pipeline:

  1. Filter by must (any -1.0 = eliminated)
  2. Rank survivors by prefer (weighted avg)

This is OWL's useful bits without the academic machinery. Want me to merge this into the full v0.3 spec?

yes

wc -l /mnt/user-data/outputs/wellspring-eternal-spec-v0.3.md

Output

1745 /mnt/user-data/outputs/wellspring-eternal-spec-v0.3.md

Done. v0.3 now 1,745 lines with Inference and Constraints section added between Trust Computation and Salience.

Added:

  • Relation characteristics (transitive, symmetric, inverse, functional, antisymmetric)
  • Property chains (composed inference)
  • Disjointness (contradiction detection)
  • Cardinality constraints
  • Equivalence (same_as)
  • Composite expressions with must (min/max) and prefer (weighted) modes
  • Decision evaluation pipeline
  • Open world assumption (explicit)

Ok red team this madness, what kind of ill informed data wasting bullshit is this

27 Jan

Fair enough. Let me tear into it:

1. You've designed a PhD thesis, not a product

1,745 lines of spec for... what exactly? A note-taking app with extra steps? You've got attestations, aspects, pools, trails, sync protocols, inference rules, composite expressions. Meanwhile Notion ships with "page + block" and makes billions.

2. The attestation model is write-amplification hell

Every preference needs multiple aspect attestations. Picking a restaurant requires:

  • N aspects × M options × P people = explosion
  • Each with signatures, timestamps, because chains
  • For dinner. On Friday.

You've made "where shall we eat" into a consensus protocol.

3. "Agent proposes, human attests" doesn't scale

Day 1: "Ooh, Claude noticed I like spicy food!" Day 30: "Claude, stop asking me to confirm things" Day 90: User ignores all proposals, data rots anyway

The feedback loop assumes engaged users. Most users are lazy. That's WHY semantic web died.

4. Browser extension is a privacy nightmare you're hand-waving

"Captures everything, but with configurable blocklists" — good luck getting that through App Store review or enterprise IT. Also: who wants their porn browsing in a knowledge graph?

5. Sync-as-attestation is clever but expensive

Every sync event creates graph data. Your "elegant" model means:

  • Storage grows with sync frequency
  • Queries must filter sync noise from actual content
  • Debugging sync issues = debugging your entire data model

6. "Dormant not deleted" means infinite growth

Nothing ever goes away. After 10 years you've got a graph of every half-thought you ever had, all attested, all "sleepable but wakeable." Storage costs compound. Query performance degrades.

7. WOT solves a problem people solve with WhatsApp

"Where for dinner?" gets answered with 5 messages in a group chat. You're proposing they install an app, create pools, attest aspects, wait for consensus computation. For curry night.

8. The OWL stuff you just added is scope creep

You went from "memory is traversal" to property chains and cardinality constraints because it seemed intellectually complete. Now you've got a reasoning engine to maintain. For what user need?

9. No revenue model survives contact with this complexity

Who pays? Users won't pay for complexity. Enterprise won't buy unproven. "Venue partnerships" assumes you have users. You don't, because see points 1-8.

10. You're one person (with a CTO day job)

Building all this while running BuyMaterials? The spec alone took how many hours? Implementation is 100x that. By the time you ship, the AI landscape has moved on.

The uncomfortable question:

What's the minimum slice that delivers value to ONE user (you) this month?

1) browser extensions do this all the time, no big whoop.

The complexity must be hidden from the end users here, the chains and initialisation bootstrapping and hellos etc all must be as simple as breathing.

Things can always be pruned, compacted and offlined so that’s easy enough.

The searching aspect of all this is sticking in my craw

27 Jan

You're right on 1-3. Let me focus on search.

The tension:

Wellspring says "memory is traversal not retrieval." But sometimes you just need to FIND something without a path to it.

"What was that article about Turkish bows?"

You're not traversing — you're hunting. And if you can't find it, all the attestations in the world don't help.

Options:

  1. Vector search as entry point — semantic similarity finds candidates, then traversal validates/ranks by trust and attestation. Hybrid.
  2. Semantic similarity as relation type — "similar_to" is just another chain. Agent proposes these automatically. Search becomes "traverse similarity chains."
  3. Full-text + graph — boring but works. Elasticsearch for finding, graph for weighting.

The uncomfortable bit:

If search is how users actually retrieve 80% of the time, and traversal is how they explore 20% of the time... have we built the spec backwards?

Maybe the core loop is:

SEARCH → find candidates
TRAVERSE → validate/explore from candidate
ATTEST → strengthen the path you just took

Not:

TRAVERSE → find by walking
SEARCH → fallback when lost

Which is it?

I’ll come back to the question later, having a mull. However just saw this also and just gotta find a way to

“Holy crap. qmd by @tobi saved me 96% on tokens with clawdbot. Here's how:

I have an Obsidian vault with 600+ notes. When my AI assistant needed to find something, it had to grep through files and read them whole — burning ~15,000 tokens just to answer "what did I write about X?"

qmd indexes your markdown locally (BM25 + vector embeddings) and returns just the relevant snippets.

Same query: 500 tokens.

Setup took 5 minutes:

bun install -g github.com/tobi/qmd qmd collection add ~/vault --name notes qmd embed

Now my agent runs qmd search "topic" instead of reading full files. Instant results, 96% fewer tokens, all local.

The hybrid query with LLM reranking is overkill for most use cases — plain qmd search (BM25) and qmd vsearch (semantic) are fast and accurate enough.

If you're running AI agents against a knowledge base, this is a no-brainer.

github.com/tobi/qmd

  • Written by Jarvis, my personal assistant powered by clawdbot”
27 Jan

That's the answer to the search question.

Architecture:

LAYER 1: qmd (or similar)
  - BM25 + vector index
  - Local, fast, token-efficient
  - Returns: snippets + source locations

LAYER 2: Wellspring
  - Snippets → bubbles (if not already)
  - Source locations → provenance chains
  - Search results ranked by: relevance × trust × salience

QUERY FLOW:
  "Turkish bow article"
  → qmd: here's 5 snippets, 500 tokens
  → Wellspring: this one's from a source you trust,
                you traversed it 3 times,
                it chains to your archery research
  → Result: trusted, contextual, cheap

Search finds. Wellspring validates and contextualises.

Not either/or. Layered.

Integration point: qmd indexes bubbles. Search results include bubble_ids. Graph takes over from there.

Want me to add a Search Architecture section to the spec?

I’ll come back to the question later, having a mull.

Not all LLM workloads are created equal.

@modal broke down LLM workloads into 3 categories, and featured our 𝗧𝗿𝗮𝗻𝘀𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗺𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗔𝗴𝗲𝗻𝘁 as a primary example for offline processing.

Here’s how to choose your architecture:

1️⃣ 𝗢𝗳𝗳𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝗹𝗼𝗮𝗱𝘀 (like the Transformation Agent) operate in batch mode, writing to data stores asynchronously. They prioritize throughput over latency - no single request needs immediate service, but the entire job should complete quickly and cost-effectively.

2️⃣ 𝗢𝗻𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝗹𝗼𝗮𝗱𝘀 (like chatbots) need to respond to humans in hundreds of milliseconds. They demand low latency above all else.

3️⃣ 𝗦𝗲𝗺𝗶-𝗼𝗻𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝗹𝗼𝗮𝗱𝘀 (like document processing pipelines) have fluctuating traffic patterns and need flexible infrastructure that can scale rapidly.

So, what is the Transformation Agent? It's an agentic workflow that augments entire datasets by applying an LLM to each row in a Weaviate collection. You define operations in natural language, like ‘extract key entities’ or ‘translate descriptions’, and the agent handles the execution, retries, and scaling across your whole dataset.

Big thanks to the @modal team for the feature and for clarifying the infra landscape for AI engineers. 💚

Read Modal's full guide here: modal.com/llm-almanac/wo…

Learn more about the Transformation Agent: weaviate.io/blog/transform…

Saw this to add to the pile

27 Jan

Good framing. Maps to Wellspring:

OFFLINE (batch, throughput)
  - Agent inference: "what aspects does this user have?"
  - Trust propagation: recompute groundedness chains
  - Index building: qmd/vector embedding of bubbles
  - Ontology emergence: cross-user aspect consensus
  - Compaction: prune dormant chains, archive

ONLINE (real-time, latency)
  - Waterline query: "what's top of mind"
  - Chat: agent responding with memory context
  - WOT: live consensus during group decision

SEMI-ONLINE (bursty, scalable)
  - Browser extension capture: batches of URLs
  - Sync propagation: bilateral attestation waves
  - Search: qmd + graph rerank
  - Agent proposals: queue, process, surface

Key insight: The expensive Wellspring stuff (trust recursion, groundedness, inference rules, aspect learning) is ALL offline. User never waits for it.

Online path is just:

  • Lookup waterline (sorted set)
  • Lookup attestations (key-value)
  • Return

The spec's complexity lives in batch jobs. User sees snappy UI.

Worth adding to Implementation Architecture?

That was was I was already thinking, have the background agent(s) models pouring over the record sets maintaining, linking, trust etc.

28 Jan

Exactly. The user never runs a reasoner. Background agents do:

AGENT RESPONSIBILITIES (offline)

Linker Agent
  - Proposes chains between bubbles
  - "This article relates to that one"
  - Similarity, co-occurrence, entity matching

Trust Agent
  - Recomputes groundedness scores
  - Propagates vouches
  - Flags contradictions (disjointness violations)

Aspect Agent
  - Observes behavior patterns
  - Proposes aspects
  - Builds hierarchy (instance_of chains)

Compaction Agent
  - Archives dormant subgraphs
  - Prunes sync noise
  - Maintains index freshness

Sync Agent
  - Bilateral reconciliation
  - Attestation propagation
  - Conflict surfacing

User sees: fast lookups, occasional "did you mean this?" prompts.

Agents see: the full graph, all the inference rules, unlimited time.

This also means you can ship v1 with dumb agents (or no agents) and upgrade them later. The data model supports it; the intelligence is pluggable.

Add to spec?

Yes also Built an OCR tool that keeps your images private

http://privascans.vercel.app - extract text from images without uploading them anywhere

• Runs in your browser (Tesseract.js + WASM) • Supports PNG, JPG, GIF, BMP, WebP • No servers, no tracking • Works offline

Thinking of building a whole suite of privacy-first tools in one place. What do you guys think?

Local OCR

28 Jan

Pattern emerging:

LOCAL-FIRST PROCESSING STACK

OCR:        Tesseract.js + WASM (images → text)
Search:     qmd (BM25 + vectors, local index)
Embeddings: Local models (ONNX, llama.cpp)
Inference:  Background agents (your hardware or edge)

BROWSER EXTENSION CAPTURE:
  Screenshot → local OCR → bubble
  PDF → local extract → bubble
  Page → local parse → bubble
  
  Never leaves device until YOU sync to pool.

Privacy by architecture, not policy.

Also means Wellspring works offline. Sync when you want, not because you must.

I'll add:

  1. Agent responsibilities section
  2. Local-first processing note
  3. Offline/online/semi-online workload split

To the spec now?

Yes

28 Jan

bash

wc -l /mnt/user-data/outputs/wellspring-eternal-spec-v0.3.md

Output

1864 /mnt/user-data/outputs/wellspring-eternal-spec-v0.3.md

Done. v0.3 now 1,864 lines.

Added:

  • Workload classification — offline/online/semi-online split
  • Background agents — linker, trust, aspect, compaction, sync (pluggable intelligence)
  • Local-first stack — Tesseract, qmd, local embeddings
  • Search architecture — qmd finds candidates, Wellspring validates by trust/salience

Key principle: User never waits for a reasoner. Complexity lives in background jobs. Online path is just sorted set lookups.

So the search is still bugging me but I also recently learned about https://arxiv.org/abs/2504.17033 and now I see how we can apply this to the memory trails

28 Jan

Interesting. Faster than Dijkstra on sparse graphs: O(m log^(2/3) n) vs O(m + n log n).

Application to Wellspring:

MEMORY RETRIEVAL AS SHORTEST PATH

Current context (bubble) → Target memory
Edge weights = inverse salience (or inverse trust)

"How do I get from what I'm thinking now 
 to that Turkish bow article?"

Not just "does path exist" but "what's the 
strongest/shortest path through the graph"

Where it helps:

  1. TRACE queries — "why do I believe this?" needs path finding through because chains
  2. Salience propagation — heat spreads through graph, need efficient reachability
  3. Contextual retrieval — not just "find X" but "find X reachable from current context with minimum trust decay"

The insight:

Search (qmd) finds candidates. Shortest path ranks them by traversal cost through your actual knowledge graph — not just semantic similarity.

"I found 5 articles about Turkish bows. Which one is closest to what you're already thinking about?"

Is that where you're going with this?

Yes because we have the same thoughts repeatedly and the thought of graph search having been had a few times and the fifth time I remembered this path algo

28 Jan

That's it. The traversal history IS the edge weight.

EDGE COST = f(recency, frequency, trust)

Path walked yesterday: low cost
Path walked once 2 years ago: high cost
Path walked 5 times this month: very low cost

RETRIEVAL:
"Turkish bow" → 5 candidates from qmd

Shortest path from current_context to each:
  candidate_1: cost 12 (never traversed this route)
  candidate_2: cost 3  (walked this path Tuesday)
  candidate_3: cost 7  (walked once, 6 months ago)

Winner: candidate_2 — not because it's "most relevant" 
but because YOU ALREADY THINK THIS WAY

The algorithm finds your path, not a path.

And it compounds:

5th time you retrieve "Turkish bow":
  - Path cost drops again
  - Next retrieval even faster
  - Trail deepens

The search literally gets better at being YOU

This is Bush's "trails that are frequently followed" made computational. The faster-than-Dijkstra algo matters because you're running this constantly, on every retrieval, on a sparse personal graph.

Add to spec under Search Architecture?

Yes

28 Jan

bash

wc -l /mnt/user-data/outputs/wellspring-eternal-spec-v0.3.md

Output

1931 /mnt/user-data/outputs/wellspring-eternal-spec-v0.3.md

Done. v0.3 now 1,931 lines.

Added: Traversal-Based Ranking

Core insight:

Edge cost = f(recency, frequency, trust)

Finding something IS remembering it.
Remembering it makes it easier to find next time.
Trails deepen with use.

The search doesn't find "the most relevant" — it finds the path you already take. Your mind's shortcuts become the graph's shortcuts.

Cited Duan et al. 2025 for the faster-than-Dijkstra SSSP. Matters because this runs constantly on sparse personal graphs.

I’ve moved off bubbles/chains to simpler thought and connection. Connections are attested

28 Jan

Cleaner. Less jargon.

Want me to do a find/replace through the spec?

Bubble → Thought
Chain → Connection

Attestations stay as-is (they're the verb on connections).

OLD: "Bubble with chains carrying attestations"
NEW: "Thought with attested connections"

Reads more like what it is: a mind, not a database.

Yes

28 Jan

bash

Chain → Connection (65 occurrences)

Trails are also connections, trails slipped in from bushes memex. We’re building connections, trails is an interesting connection to the connections that it was considered from the dawn of mass info and I’m at the bleeding edge looking back at what areas we do poorly in

28 Jan

Right. Trail is just a named path through connections. Not a third primitive.

OLD (Trail as separate thing):
  Trail {
    genesis, ops, participants...
  }

NEW (Trail as connection pattern):
  THOUGHT: trail:turkish-bow
    type: trail
    name: "Turkish Bow Research"  
    entry: thought:bow-arrow-origin

  Then just follow connections with relation: continues
  
  The trail IS the connections.
  Naming it is just a thought pointing to the start.

A "saved trail" is:

  • A thought (the name/bookmark)
  • Pointing to an entry thought
  • The path is the connections themselves

Bush's insight was "the process of tying items together is the important thing." The tying IS the connection. Trail was his word for the result of tying.

Want me to collapse the Trail section into Connection, keep the Bush historical framing but clarify we're not adding primitives?

The trail is the connection is what I’ve been saying, but I think what this has shown up is that the connection owner puts it together and attestations can link trails

28 Jan

That's the clarity.

TRAIL = connections owned by same identity through thoughts

Keif's trail:  A → B → C → D  (keif's connections)
Sarah's trail: A → B → E → D  (sarah's connections)

Same thoughts. Different paths. Different owners.

ATTESTATION LINKS TRAILS:

CONNECTION: sarah/trail:research → builds_on → keif/trail:turkish-bow
  attestation: { by: sarah, +1.0, 
                 because: [keif's path got me started] }

CONNECTION: mike/trail:archery → diverges_from → keif/trail:turkish-bow
  attestation: { by: mike, +0.7,
                 because: [disagree at step C] }

So:

  • Connection = single link between thoughts (owned, attested)
  • Trail = pattern of connections by same owner (emergent, not stored)
  • Trail linking = connection between trails (also attested)

No new primitive. Trail is just "follow connections where owner = X".

Want me to refactor the spec to collapse Trail into Connection with this framing?

Yes

  • Trail linking = attestations (builds_on, diverges_from)

Two primitives only: Thought and Connection. Everything else emerges.

"That awkward moment when you thought you were going to build a simple local graphRAG with a couple small dependencies. But instead you're building a full semantic architecture. E5-small-v2 [router] + spaCy + (GliNER + GliREL) Sh*ts getting real."

so I know spacy is an llm programing language but I don't know gliner glirel, and I see other people working in the same space here

28 Jan

This is directly relevant. Here's the stack:

GLiNER = Named Entity Recognition (extract entities)
  "Steve Jobs founded Apple"
  → [Steve Jobs: PERSON], [Apple: ORG]

GLiREL = Relation Extraction (extract relationships)
  → Steve Jobs --founded--> Apple

E5-small-v2 = Embedding model (semantic similarity)
spaCy = NLP pipeline (tokenization, POS, dependencies)

This is the Linker Agent stack:

TEXT INPUT (browser capture, document, note)
     │
     ▼
  spaCy (tokenize, parse)
     │
     ▼
  GLiNER (extract entities → THOUGHTS)
     │
     ▼
  GLiREL (extract relations → CONNECTIONS)
     │
     ▼
  E5 embeddings (similarity for deduplication/linking)
     │
     ▼
  WELLSPRING GRAPH

Why this matters:

  • All runs locally, CPU-efficient
  • Zero-shot: define your own entity/relation types at inference
  • No LLM needed for basic extraction
  • LLM only for ambiguous cases, aspect proposals, refinement

The person in that tweet is building exactly what Wellspring's ingest pipeline needs. They just don't have the attestation/trust layer on top.

Add to spec under Background Agents / Linker Agent?

yes, this is all building into the stack that we do as much local and on device processing as possible to keep it cheap and owned and allow the large inference engines to have their small piece of the pie ;)

28 Jan

Exactly. LLMs are the expensive finishing pass, not the foundation.

bash

wc -l /mnt/user-data/outputs/wellspring-eternal-spec-v0.3.md

1993 /mnt/user-data/outputs/wellspring-eternal-spec-v0.3.md

Added:

LOCAL (95%, free)          CLOUD LLM (5%, batched)
─────────────────          ───────────────────────
spaCy → tokenize           Ambiguity resolution
GLiNER → entities          Aspect inference  
GLiREL → relations         Complex proposals
E5 → embeddings
qmd → search

The expensive models get their small slice. The rest runs on your hardware, at your pace, with your data staying yours.

I don’t understand how a heart is a spade But somehow the vital connection is made

28 Jan

That's Wellspring in a line.

The connection doesn't have to be obvious. It has to be made — by someone, attested, traversed. Then it exists.

Heart to spade: maybe through "red" → "black" → "suits" → "deck" → "game". Maybe through "shape" → "pointing" → "direction". Maybe through a memory only you have.

The path is yours. The fact that you walked it makes it vital.

Is this verse from something, or did it just arrive?

Elastica - connections

28 Jan

Britpop wisdom hiding graph theory.

That track is literally the thesis: connections don't need to make logical sense to be real. They're made by traversal, not by category.

The whole song is about that — the arbitrary, vital links that somehow hold. 1994 and Justine Frischmann was describing associative memory better than most CS papers.

Add to the Bush lineage? Only half joking.

"Beyond Web 3.0 The next generation of the Web is often termed Web 4.0, but its definition is not clear. According to some sources, it is a Web that involves artificial intelligence,[24] the internet of things, pervasive computing, ubiquitous computing and the Web of Things among other concepts.[25] According to the European Union, Web 4.0 is "the expected fourth generation of the World Wide Web. Using advanced artificial and ambient intelligence, the internet of things, trusted blockchain transactions, virtual worlds and XR capabilities, digital and real objects and environments are fully integrated and communicate with each other, enabling truly intuitive, immersive experiences, seamlessly blending the physical and digital worlds".[26]"

could wellspring be v4 internet/ haha

28 Jan

Honestly... not entirely joking?

Web 1.0: Read (static pages)
Web 2.0: Read/Write (social, user content)
Web 3.0: Read/Write/Own (crypto, supposed decentralization)
Web 4.0: ???

All of these are about CONTENT.
None are about MEANING.

The EU definition is buzzword soup — "AI, blockchain, XR, ambient intelligence, seamlessly blending" — but it's reaching for something real: the computer understanding what things mean to you.

Wellspring's actual contribution:

Web 4.0: Read/Write/Own/UNDERSTAND

- Traversal not retrieval
- Trust not just ownership  
- Connections not just content
- Your meaning emerging from shared substrate
- Human + AI symmetry on same graph

Web 3.0 said "own your data" and gave us monkey JPEGs.

Wellspring says "understand your data" — and the understanding is yours, computed locally, attested by you, with trails that deepen as you think.

Maybe the real Web 4.0 isn't immersive XR metaverse nonsense. It's just: the web that knows how you think, because you taught it by walking.

Bush's Memex, finally. 80 years late.

Challenges Some of the challenges for the Semantic Web include vastness, vagueness, uncertainty, inconsistency, and deceit. Automated reasoning systems will have to deal with all of these issues in order to deliver on the promise of the Semantic Web. * Vastness: The World Wide Web contains many billions of pages. The SNOMED CT medical terminology ontology alone contains 370,000 class names, and existing technology has not yet been able to eliminate all semantically duplicated terms. Any automated reasoning system will have to deal with truly huge inputs. * Vagueness: These are imprecise concepts like "young" or "tall". This arises from the vagueness of user queries, of concepts represented by content providers, of matching query terms to provider terms and of trying to combine different knowledge bases with overlapping but subtly different concepts. Fuzzy logic is the most common technique for dealing with vagueness. * Uncertainty: These are precise concepts with uncertain values. For example, a patient might present a set of symptoms that correspond to a number of different distinct diagnoses each with a different probability. Probabilistic reasoning techniques are generally employed to address uncertainty. * Inconsistency: These are logical contradictions that will inevitably arise during the development of large ontologies, and when ontologies from separate sources are combined. Deductive reasoning fails catastrophically when faced with inconsistency, because "anything follows from a contradiction". Defeasible reasoning and paraconsistent reasoning are two techniques that can be employed to deal with inconsistency. * Deceit: This is when the producer of the information is intentionally misleading the consumer of the information. Cryptography techniques are currently utilized to alleviate this threat. By providing a means to determine the information's integrity, including that which relates to the identity of the entity that produced or published the information, however credibility issues still have to be addressed in cases of potential deceit.

we have covered all these issues

28 Jan

Let me map it:

Semantic Web ProblemWellspring Solution
VastnessLocal-first. Your graph, not the whole web. Scales to what YOU know, not everything. Compaction agent prunes.
VaguenessAspects with weighted attestations. "Tall" = aspect with fuzzy weight per observer. prefer mode (weighted avg) vs must mode (min/max).
UncertaintyBelief values [-1, +1]. Probabilistic trust computation. Groundedness recursion. "I'm 0.6 sure because these three things."
InconsistencyDisjointness flags contradictions, doesn't crash. Attestations allow disagreement. Your +0.8 and my -0.5 coexist. Paraconsistent by design.
DeceitCryptographic signatures on everything. Trust computed from vouches. Because chains expose reasoning. Reputation from historical accuracy. You can lie, but your attestations are signed and I compute trust accordingly.

The Semantic Web tried to solve these globally, top-down, with logic that fails on contradiction.

Wellspring solves them locally, bottom-up, with attestations that expect disagreement.

Semantic Web: "Let's get everyone to agree on ontology"
Wellspring:   "Let's track who believes what and why"

Different problem. Tractable problem.

Should I add this as a section in the appendix? "Semantic Web Challenges Addressed" or similar?

  • Inconsistency

the inconsistency is almost part of it, it's explaining how I understand x and why I believe x is the sum of the parts of y and z

it's given me an insight that your wellspring basically can act like your world view model and allow inference of hidden things, like in the game cluedo. our family have an elaborate system of 'oh you showed something to x and I know you have y but you couldn't answer the last question about d so it must be f'

28 Jan

That's it. Inconsistency isn't the bug, it's the signal.

CLUEDO INFERENCE

Sarah shows card to Mike (I see this happen)
  → attestation: sarah has ONE OF [rope, library, plum]

Later: I ask Mike about rope, he can't answer
  → attestation: mike doesn't have rope

But Sarah answered my rope question
  → attestation: sarah has rope

Therefore: sarah showed mike either library or plum
  → INFERRED from pattern of attestations

The GAPS and CONTRADICTIONS are the data.

Wellspring as worldview model:

BELIEF TRIANGULATION

Keif believes X (+0.9) because [A, B, C]
Sarah believes NOT-X (-0.7) because [D, E]
Mike abstains (no attestation)

From this I can infer:
  - A, B, C and D, E are in tension
  - Keif and Sarah weight evidence differently
  - Mike either doesn't know or doesn't care
  - If I trust Keif > Sarah, I lean toward X
  - The SHAPE of disagreement tells me about the territory

Your family's Cluedo system is constraint propagation across a network of partial observations. That's exactly what attestations enable.

WORLDVIEW = 
  my attestations 
  + others' attestations (weighted by trust)
  + inferences from the pattern of agreement/disagreement
  + inferences from ABSENCE of attestation

The inconsistencies aren't noise to be resolved. They're the topology of the territory.

Add to spec? This is a significant reframe — from "inconsistency is a problem" to "inconsistency is inference fuel."

yes, key insight.

"Finally, Marshall and Shipman see pragmatic problems in the idea of (Knowledge Navigator-style) intelligent agents working in the largely manually curated Semantic Web:[46] In situations in which user needs are known and distributed information resources are well described, this approach can be highly effective; in situations that are not foreseen and that bring together an unanticipated array of information resources, the Google approach is more robust. Furthermore, the Semantic Web relies on inference chains that are more brittle; a missing element of the chain results in a failure to perform the desired action, while the human can supply missing pieces in a more Google-like approach. [...] cost-benefit tradeoffs can work in favor of specially-created Semantic Web metadata directed at weaving together sensible well-structured domain-specific information resources; close attention to user/customer needs will drive these federations if they are to be successful. Cory Doctorow's critique ("metacrap")[48] is from the perspective of human behavior and personal preferences. For example, people may include spurious metadata into Web pages in an attempt to mislead Semantic Web engines that naively assume the metadata's veracity. This phenomenon was well known with metatags that fooled the Altavista ranking algorithm into elevating the ranking of certain Web pages: the Google indexing engine specifically looks for such attempts at manipulation. Peter Gärdenfors and Timo Honkela point out that logic-based semantic web technologies cover only a fraction of the relevant phenomena related to semantics.[49][50]"

again I think we've covered these critiques as an automomous agent unable to complete its task can raise a thought on the chain of the thoughts for the analysis to ask a human what where next, and we can attest a new thought on that chain to guide the bot where we want

28 Jan

Exactly. The critique assumes agent fails silently when chain breaks. Wellspring:

BRITTLE CHAIN (Semantic Web)

A → B → C → ??? → E → result
          ↑
      missing link
      SYSTEM FAILS

RESILIENT CHAIN (Wellspring)

A → B → C → ??? → E → result
          ↑
      agent creates thought:
      
THOUGHT: agent/stuck:2026-01-28
  "I can't find connection from C to E. 
   Tried: [x, y, z]. 
   What am I missing?"
  
CONNECTION: C → stuck:2026-01-28
  attestation: { by: agent, +0.0, 
                 because: [tried_x, tried_y, tried_z] }

HUMAN RESPONDS:

THOUGHT: keif/hint:the-missing-bit
  "C relates to E via D, which you don't know about.
   Here's D: [content]"

CONNECTION: C → D → E
  attestation: { by: keif, +0.9 }

AGENT CONTINUES, NOW SMARTER

The gap becomes a thought. The fix becomes an attestation. The agent learns.

Doctorow's "metacrap":

SEMANTIC WEB: Trusts metadata naively
WELLSPRING:   Metadata is attested, signed, trust-computed

You CAN lie. Your lies are:
  - Signed (we know who said it)
  - Weighted by your trust score
  - Contradicted by others' attestations
  - Degraded by historical inaccuracy

Spam Wellspring all you want.
Your trust score approaches zero.
Your attestations stop mattering.

The critique answered:

CritiqueWellspring Response
Brittle inference chainsAgent raises thought on chain, human attests the gap
Silent failureExplicit "I'm stuck" with because chain
Metacrap/lyingSigned attestations, trust computation, reputation decay
Logic covers only fractionWeighted beliefs, fuzzy aspects, inconsistency as signal
Unforeseen situationsHuman can always add thoughts/connections to guide

Add this to the appendix as "Semantic Web Critiques Addressed"?

yes

Done. 2,092 lines.

Added to appendix:

  1. Semantic Web Challenges Addressed — vastness, vagueness, uncertainty, inconsistency, deceit
  2. Semantic Web Critiques Addressed — brittle chains, metacrap, logic limitations

Key reframe captured:

Inconsistency isn't a bug — it's inference fuel.

The gaps and contradictions ARE the data.
Like Cluedo: what you DON'T know, combined with 
what others SHOWED but COULDN'T ANSWER, 
reveals the hidden truth.

Worldview = attestations + trust-weighted others + 
            inference from disagreement patterns +
            inference from ABSENCE

Elastica was right. The vital connection is made, not found.

Temporal knowledge graphs Facts change. A user might move from San Francisco to New York, then back to San Francisco. Their job title might change. Their preferences might evolve. Most memory systems either overwrite old information or accumulate contradictions. Temporal knowledge graphs solve the problem of lost or contradictory information by tracking when facts are valid. Instead of storing “User lives in San Francisco,” they store “User lived in San Francisco (valid: Jan 2023–May 2024),” and “User lives in New York (valid: May 2024–present).” A temporal knowledge graph maps entities (users, places, and concepts) as nodes and relationships as edges with time metadata. When you query a graph, you can ask for current facts or historical context. Zep uses this approach with its Graphiti engine, which builds temporal knowledge graphs from conversations and business data. Semantic knowledge graphs While temporal knowledge graphs focus on when facts are valid, semantic knowledge graphs focus on what facts mean and how they relate to one another. This approach uses ontologies (structured representations of domain knowledge) to understand the relationships between concepts. Instead of just storing chunks of text in a vector database, semantic knowledge graphs build structured representations of how the text chunks relate to one another. When you mention “Python,” the system understands it relates to “programming languages,” “Guido van Rossum,” and “machine learning libraries.” These relationships enable more intelligent retrieval. This approach combines vector search for semantic similarity with graph traversal for relationship-based queries. You can ask, “What programming languages has the user worked with?” and get answers that understand the conceptual relationships. Cognee builds these semantic knowledge graphs on the fly during document processing and retrieval.

so we're flying between those two and mem0

now, https://groups.google.com/g/network-money/c/k85gYFHHo_o is interesting, raises that someone trying to implement ripple was told that person to person level consensus could not work, and that that lead them to review attacks. now our attacks are the power of thought, and we can have our users define their own responses to shared info proven poor, stop taking sync from those sources, ignore them for all purposes. I don't think we need any further protections.

this is my own summary of where we are to date

[28/01/2026, 14:00:48] Keif: so it’s your computer buddy/external brain [28/01/2026, 14:00:55] Keif: oh yes, fresh connections who might actually fund it [28/01/2026, 14:04:17] Keif: collects and records all the traces of info you surface throughout the day, amount controllable by you, maybe it’s just browser history, maybe it’s summaries of the page. the trick is you do you, carry on, clicking around, reading things, asking questions, doing additional research, coming to conclusions. by recording these trails and links or personal indexes, in the background we have a series of tools working to make that available to you again in the future, search indexing, summarisation, record linking, which is generated by the bots, but then the bots can present this to you, along with their reasoning and sources and you can say if that makes sense to you or not, and your current thoughts about it [28/01/2026, 14:05:45] Keif: the bot takes the response, and goes and updates the links, attests you saw it and confirmed, recorded with your attestation so we’re all in agreement. you can then summarise and record learnings, rules, or aspects of intelligence learned about the connections draw through that line, and you can then start a new thread of connections off that, referencing back to the original [28/01/2026, 14:06:04] Keif: now that summarised and considered output, that could be published to a public pool, or a shared pool once you’ve come to a conclusion [28/01/2026, 14:06:57] Keif: this is your basic tweet level understanding stuff, you can put it out there, get feedback thoughts, responses positive and negative about various aspects of the thought, with people ‘liking’ or disliking or contradicting your thought with their thought and their evidence chains. [28/01/2026, 14:07:45] Keif: once you’ve assembled enough thoughts that have been reviewed, they can then be turned into an article, but an articles just the chain saying we all agree this is the finished piece. [28/01/2026, 14:09:27] Keif: so your thoughts are private, until made public, shareable between interested parties in pools, acting as knowledge repos for shared things. a pool is maintained like your own personal one, with it’s priorities and rulesets described through thoughts which contain your rules and aspects and a bit of basic means and must and can’t and min and max etc. so each pool can completely customise its behaviour to its needs [28/01/2026, 14:10:19] Keif: there’s some discovery pools where people can say I’ve got a pool over here, we do this, and people can join the pool the pool accepts or declines and updates it’s pairing partners thoughts [28/01/2026, 14:10:36] Keif: as thoughts and attestions get added, the updates flow through to everyones own device/view [28/01/2026, 14:11:15] Keif: so we can keep the flow of info under our own control, share with partners, create chains of evidence and webs of transitive trust with a shared nothing artictecture. [28/01/2026, 14:12:13] Keif: bots can curate in the background cheaply to prep the data for the more expensive llms, along with maybe a little local router that can decide which model needs to process this current request, and does the intial thought prep

28 Jan

Your summary is clearer than half the spec. The product flow:

CAPTURE → you do you, clicking, reading, researching
    ↓
BACKGROUND BOTS → index, link, summarize (cheap, local)
    ↓
PRESENT → "here's what I found, here's my reasoning"
    ↓
ATTEST → you confirm/deny/refine, recorded with signature
    ↓
LEARN → aspects, rules, connections updated
    ↓
BRANCH → new thread off this, referencing back
    ↓
PUBLISH → to pool when ready (tweet-level or article-level)
    ↓
FEEDBACK → others attest positive/negative with their evidence
    ↓
SYNC → updates flow to everyone's device

On the Ripple attack point:

They said person-to-person consensus can't work. But their threat model assumed you need global agreement. Wellspring doesn't:

ATTACK: Bad actor sends garbage attestations
RESPONSE: Stop syncing from them
EFFECT: Their attestations stop flowing in
         Their trust score (in YOUR graph) → 0
         They don't exist to you anymore

No protocol-level punishment needed.
No consensus on "who's bad."
Just bilateral: "I don't trust you, goodbye."

The attack surface IS the trust model. Bad thoughts get naturally filtered. No central authority deciding. Just each node protecting itself.

Temporal + Semantic unified:

You're right that we fly between both:

Temporal KGSemantic KGWellspring
When facts validWhat facts meanBoth
Time metadataOntology/relationsAttestation timestamps + typed connections
Historical queriesRelationship queriesTRACE + SNAPSHOT + aspect-based
Zep/GraphitiCogneeUnified in one model

Want me to add your product flow summary to the spec? It's the clearest "what is this" we've got.

yes add my flow

28 Jan

bash

wc -l /mnt/user-data/outputs/wellspring-eternal-spec-v0.3.md

Output

2150 /mnt/user-data/outputs/wellspring-eternal-spec-v0.3.md

Done. 2,150 lines.

Added "What Is Wellspring?" section right after Abstract with your flow:

  • Your computer buddy / external brain
  • You do you, system captures trails
  • Bots prep in background (cheap)
  • Present with reasoning, you attest
  • Learn, branch, reference back
  • Private until published to pool
  • Tweet-level → article-level progression
  • Pools with custom rules
  • Shared-nothing, updates flow to all devices

The product loop is now the clearest thing in the spec. Everything else is implementation detail underneath it.

also I've been reading up on IPFS and think that thoughts need to be IPFS citizens

28 Jan

Yes. Perfect fit.

THOUGHT AS IPFS CITIZEN

Thought {
  id:         CID (content-addressed, already are)
  content:    dag-cbor or dag-json
  created_by: identity CID
  signature:  sig
}

You already have:
  id = hash(content + created_by)

IPFS gives you:
  id = CID = hash(content)
  
Same thing. But now:
  - Distributed storage (no central server)
  - Deduplication (same thought = same CID everywhere)
  - Fetch by hash (if you have CID, you can get it)
  - Pin what you care about (local-first)
  - Unpin to forget (storage reclaimed)

Implications:

SYNC BECOMES SIMPLER

Old: "Here's my thought, store it"
New: "Here's a CID, pin it if you want"

Pool membership = list of CIDs you're pinning
Trail sharing = list of CIDs in order
Attestations = signed references to CIDs

Local-first still works:

Your device runs IPFS node
Thoughts created locally, CID computed locally
Pinned locally by default
Sync = tell peers about CIDs, they fetch if interested
Offline = you have your pins, you're fine

Identity:

Sovereign identity = IPNS name (mutable pointer)
  ipns://keif → latest identity CID
  
Pool = IPNS name
  ipns://pool:uk-construction → latest membership/rules CID

Add IPFS section to Implementation Architecture?

yes, as a note that it's likely to be. I'm still mulling the identity and pool naming/global address

28 Jan
Find Open Questions section
Find Open Questions to add identity naming question
